INTERN WORKSITE LOCATION: Based in Amman – Jordan, with regular visits to field sites
DATES OF INTERNSHIP:  15/5/2017
LENGTH OF INTERNSHIP: 6 Months
REPORTS TO: Senior Psychologist
Mercy Corps responsibilities
For the duration of this internship assignment the intern will receive:

In Country travel related to this Internship from MC office to field locations
Work space in MC office, a laptop and phone.

PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY:
Mercy Corps (MC) is a non-profit, voluntary humanitarian aid agency, registered in the United States and Scotland with offices in more than 40 countries around the world. Mercy Corps has been addressing the humanitarian needs in Jordan through a diverse portfolio of development and relief programs for the past 12 years. Due to the current humanitarian crisis related to the continual influx of refugees from bordering Syria, Mercy Corps is expanding its emergency programming as well as development programs supporting  Jordan’ government and host communities.
Mercy Corps’ ‘Nubader: Advancing Adolescents and Youth in Jordan’ project supports Jordanian and Syrian Youth, ages 12-19, by promoting learning, coexistence and psychosocial resiliency, building social understanding, re-establishing goal planning for the future and developing livelihood pathways. The project utilizes a Profound Stress and Attunement (PSA) model that uses neurological science to understand the impact that long term stress has on the emotional brain. Through life-skills trainings, awareness sessions and other community initiatives, Nubader engages vulnerable young people, as well as caregivers and community leaders, working to strengthen their well-being and lay the foundation for a peaceful and prosperous future.  Mercy Corps partners with local CBOs to build Community Action Hubs that provide young people with a safe space to improve social stability and ultimately make youth and their communities more resilient.
GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY:
The Intern Psychologist will provide support to the implementation of Advancing Adolescents and Youth in Jordan (Nubader) Project. He/she will work alongside the senior psychologist and will support in the development of the Wellness Centers.
The Intern Psychologist will also spend several days a week in the  field supporting the field teams in ensuring that time management involves developing training material and preparing for trainings.
LEARNING OBJECTIVES:  
Through the internship, the intern will acquire:

Understanding Profound stress and attunement approach.
Understanding wellbeing center concept.
Experience work with youth development.
Understand of unique model of Nubader Men and Women Programs.

DELIVERABLES:
The intern is expected to provide support to the team in terms of:

Support the development and implementation of community action hubs' wellness center case managers and mentors capacity building plan;
Assist in operationalization of Wellness Center systems and mechanisms such as referrals and notes of concern;
Follow-up on  volunteer platform to support Wellness Centre's counseling and support services;
Participate with wellness center team in learning circles for the Wellness Centers teams to support offering awareness and information sessions to young adults and families in the community; 
Contribute to monitoring and evaluation efforts in accordance with the plan, including monitoring, data collection, analysis, report writing.
With Senior Program Psychologist and Project Manager review and evaluate high level notes of concerns and support partners and developing action plans for young adults and their families.
Provide support to wellbeing staff including staff care session, enhancing their self-care practice.
Provide support to Wellness center and partners on national referral pathways for youth and their families who require a greater level of psychosocial intervention and support;
Provide training under the profound stress/attunement framework on trends and related issues, as well as psychosocial support, and be a part of the training team on this model;
Consult with other agencies and organizations in the delivery of awareness campaigns and specialized information sessions in response to the community needs;

About BouncBox
BounceBox is the newest trampoline park in Egypt. Located at Maxim Mall in new Cairo, we will have all your favorite indoor trampoline activities along with a couple of new challenges and surprises that will provide hours of fun for the whole family. We are currently looking for a Park Manager to run the day to day operations in coordination the Managing Partners. Trampoline parks are fast paced, fun, energetic and thriving leisure facilities, offering young children to adults a wide range of extreme activities, including fitness and training, and of course FUN.
 
As Park Manager you will be experienced within the Entertainment/Leisure industry, possessing excellent customer service skills. This is a really hands on role, with duties including ensuring all aspects of Health and Safety are adhered to, implementing strategies and processes for the park, and supporting senior management team in all areas of the park. You will be a key-holder, opening and / or closing the park on a daily basis, ensuring the park operates smoothly throughout its opening hours. You will be responsible overseeing that all staff are undertaking and completing their designated jobs, whilst maintaining the highest standards of service throughout the park at all times.
 
The ideal candidate for this role will be a self-starter, motivated and energetic individual, with excellent leadership skills, while a professional background in sports, leisure or entertainment would be ideal. It is essential that you have a clear understanding of Health and Safety, be happy to work under pressure and meet deadlines on a daily basis. Whilst this job is great fun and the hours may be flexible, you will be expected to work evenings, weekends and holidays as per an industry-standard shift rotation. A CPR / First-Aid certificate would be a plus, and certification will be a requisite for non-holders upon hiring. 
 
Our successful Park Manager will have:
•Previous experience in a busy leisure/retail environment in a management position
•Experience in managing a team with proven leadership qualities necessary to motivate and develop the team
•Strong Customer Service experience
 
Position Description:
•Assists in interviewing and selecting qualified candidates to hire
•Provides training, instruction and guidance to all staff members & serves as the park's chief culture enforcer
•Supervises weekly work schedules along with monitoring staff punctuality and attendance
•Enforces the rules in place for all positions, ensuring the safety of both customers and staff; counsels and disciplines all staff members.
•Responsible for the operation and profitability of the Trampoline Park in addition to the safety and cleanliness of the entire facility.
•    Superior organization skills are essential. You will be overseeing many moving parts of the business & as many as 10 part time employees.
 
Core Responsibilities
•    Park Operations
•    Park Profitability
•    The hiring, training, development, promotion, counseling of staff
•    Staff work Schedules
•    Park Cleanliness
•    Safety of customers & employees
•    Overall adherence to processes and policies
•    Performance oversight of staff
•    Customer Relations
 
Required Knowledge, Skills, and Abilities
•    Extensive knowledge (5+ years) with Retail / Leisure management experience
•    Extensive knowledge of handling personnel matters and team management
•    Budgeting and arithmetic skills
•    Excellent communication skills
•    Ability to balance the needs of guests and employees simultaneously
•    Exceptional Customer Service skills
•    Computer, Internet & Social Media  knowledge
 
Education and Experience
•    Bachelor’s Degree
•    5+ years in Retail/ Leisure management position

BACKGROUND:
The Syria crisis is often described as the worst humanitarian catastrophe since the end of the Cold War. Inside Syria, 7.6 million people are internally displaced and 12.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance, with 4.8 million in hard-to-reach areas. There are 4 million Syrian refugees in neighboring countries. This is no short-term humanitarian episode. The devastating human consequences to huge numbers of people will endure for decades. The destruction of relationships, communities, livelihoods, homes and infrastructure will take years to repair.
IRC is offering a robust humanitarian response to the Syria crisis. With an annual budget in excess of $140 million and a rapidly expanding portfolio, supported by more than 1,250 staff in the region, IRC is undertaking programs in Syria and the neighboring countries of Turkey, Iraq, Lebanon and Jordan in the fields of health, child protection, education, women’s protection and empowerment, NFI and food distribution, cash assistance, water and sanitation, and livelihood programming. Our work in these challenging settings gives rise to some of the most pressing issues facing contemporary humanitarian action, including questions of access, security, funding and coordination.
• SCOPE OF WORK:
The consulting psychiatrist will be responsible for supporting the mental health care activities provided by the mental health team, and the primary care providers inside Syria, in addition to providing continuous specialized training to ensure the preeminent care with model practice.
 
• RESPONSIBILITIES:
The consulting Psychiatrist will work in IRC’s Jordan office, and will work closely with the Psychiatrist, two Psychologists, and the MH pharmacists inside Syria. The consulting Psychiatrist will report directly to the Health Manager in the IRC Jordan office.

Provide regularly weekly caseload consultation to MH team. These consultations are typically conducted by telephone/ Skype and focus primarily on unstable patients or who are newly diagnose and are not improving as expected.
Suggest treatment plan changes, including medication recommendations for patients who are not improving as expected. 
Discuss patients who need referral for additional specialty health care services and advise on treatment plans until patients are engaged in such care. 
Direct evaluation of patients, focusing on clients with diagnostic or therapeutic challenges who are identified in discussion with the patient’s Case Manager and / or Psychiatrist.
Involve in development and delivery of in‐service training for primary care‐based providers and staff regarding current understanding of best practices for the recognition and treatment of behavioral health conditions in primary care.
Be available to provide occasional ad hoc telephone consultation to medical providers for very complex patients or challenging patient situations.
Respond to telephone calls from medical providers and behavioral health care managers within one business day, and respond to urgent telephone calls within one hour.
Maintain interdisciplinary treatment by reviewing treatment plans and progress; consulting and collaborating with primary care physicians, psychologist, nurses, and other health care providers.
Assure quality and safe service for patients and staff by enforcing policies, procedures, standards, rules and regulations; participating in utilization reviews; remaining available for emergency consultations.
Update job knowledge by participating in continuing medical educational opportunities; reading professional publications; maintaining personal networks; participating in professional organizations.
Enhances department and organization reputation by accepting ownership for accomplishing new and different requests; exploring opportunities to add value to job accomplishments.
Undertake other tasks as assigned by the IRC supervisor to enable and contribute to IRC’s programming.

MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS:
• Licensed psychiatrist with 5 years of experience in a psychiatric care
• Previous NGO experience is preferred.
• Experience in providing trainings, holding a ToT of mhGAP is preferable.
• Ability to work under pressure and to meet deadlines.
• Experience in conducting medical trainings.
• Strong liaison, diplomatic skills, and ability to handle stress.
• Computer skills, Microsoft Word and Excel.
• Fluency in Arabic and English, both written and spoken is required.
• Good team player.
• Ability to communicate and maintain appropriate and productive relations with a range of actors, including children, parents, local and national authorities.
• Documentation Skills, Analyzing Information in a confidential way.
• Decision Making, Listening, Verbal Communication, Patient Services, Mental Health, Psychiatry, Building Relationships, Discretion, Bedside Manner.
Language Skills:  Fluency in Arabic and English is required.

Caseload focused consultation (8 hours/ week).

Program Summary 
The goal of USAID CEP is to leave behind stronger, more cohesive and resilient partner communities in Irbid, Mafraq, Tafileh, and Ma’an. This goal will be achieved by working through, and building the capacity of, Community Enhancement Teams (CETs), municipalities/local governments, and Community Based Organizations (CBOs) as key stakeholders to:

Engage in a continuous, conflict-sensitive participatory process of identification and prioritization of stressors;
Develop immediate and long-term solutions by accessing available resources through collaboration and partnerships with relevant stakeholders (including, when appropriate, informal leaders); and,
Utilize effective and transparent communication mechanisms in support of increased community cohesion.

USAID CEP uses a transparent mobilization process as the entry point into partner communities, conducting household perception surveys and facilitating community-wide meetings to identify key stressors facing communities and form a Community Enhancement Team (CET). Throughout the life of the program, the CET serves not only as a key stakeholder, but also as USAID CEP’s primary counterpart. To affect the necessary behavior change to achieve the intended goal of leaving behind stronger, more resilient communities, USAID CEP implements three sets of integrated activities:

Community Engagement: Working closely with the CETs, USAID CEP facilitates the design and implementation of solutions for prioritized community-identified stressors.
Networking: Networking activities are designed to strengthen the key stakeholders’ ability to form partnerships, mobilize additional resources, share experiences, and strengthen intracommunity cohesion.
Conflict Management and Mitigation (CMM): To ensure that key stakeholders are equipped to operate in a fluid, complex environment and can effectively respond to emerging challenges, USAID CEP incorporates basic CMM training and offers a response mechanism to shocks and emerging stressors.

BACKGROUND:
The International Rescue Committee (IRC) responds to the world’s worst humanitarian crises and helps people to survive and rebuild their lives. Founded in 1933 at the request of Albert Einstein, the IRC offers lifesaving care and life-changing assistance to refugees forced to flee from war or disaster. At work today in over 40 countries and 22 U.S. cities, we restore safety, dignity and hope to millions who are uprooted and struggling to endure. The IRC leads the way from harm to home.
Since 2007, IRC has worked with refugees and other vulnerable populations in Jordan.  IRC’s programs in Jordan focus on urban interventions in the north that address gender-based violence specifically violence against women and girls for Syrian refugees and host community members as well as reproductive health care to Syrian refugees through three clinics based in Ramtha,Mafraq and zaatari.  Since January 2013, IRC also carries out Child Protection programs in Syrian refugee camps, providing specialized services for the identification, support and protection of unaccompanied children (UAC) and other children at risk.

Gender Equability & Transformation Manager /CARE international in Jordan
 
 
 
CARE International began work in Jordan in 1948 to meet the needs of Palestinian refugees displaced with the creation of Israel. CARE’s vision is of a world in which poverty has been overcome and all people live in dignity and security. We hold gender equality to be a fundamental requirement for poverty reduction and social justice, and the area in which we see the most pressing need for global change in order to reach our vision. Together with gender inequality, we recognize humanitarian crises – including conflict, disasters and situations of chronic insecurity – as among the most important threats to realizing our vision for a just world. In partnership with others, we deliver impactful, sustainable and evidence-driven results because of our long-term commitment to communities and our focus on addressing the underlying causes of poverty and social injustice.
Within its 69 years of operation, CARE Jordan’s programs address the needs of both the Jordanian and refugee populations. Recognizing that women and children suffer disproportionally from poverty, CARE Jordan places special emphasis on working with women to create permanent social change.
Currently, our work in Jordan prioritizes the following program areas:
 
Humanitarian Response: People affected by humanitarian crises are better able to protect themselves and their families, and receive quality humanitarian assistance.
Women’s Empowerment: Women and girls are better able to promote their social, economic, political, civil and cultural rights and well-being.
Youth engagement and empowerment: Linking youth engagement with youth empowerment initiatives.
CARE Jordan’s humanitarian response strategy includes managing a protection program in the urban settings in Amman, Irbid, Zarka, Mafraq and Azrak town; comprising of information provision, case management, emergency cash assistance, non-food items, conditional cash for education, psychosocial support, and contributing to enhancing livelihood opportunities. In addition, CARE is providing community services in Azraq Camp, with the aim to improve access to vital services, improve participation, accountability and contribute to a dignified life of the Syrian refugees currently living in Azraq camp.
CARE Jordan’s Women Empowerment Program, focuses on (1) Women’s Economic Empowerment where women are able to earn a living in a dignified and sustainable manner. (2) Gender-based Violence; the prevalence and social acceptance of gender-based violence has significantly decreased, and (3) Women’s Voice where women and girls increasingly exercise their rights to participate in decision-making in public and private spaces, at all levels.
Youth engagement and empowerment: Linking youth engagement with youth empowerment initiatives, and resulting in the development of a CARE model embracing both concepts and with a distinct focus on female as well as male youth.
CARE International in Jordan has a vacancy for the post of Gender Equability & Transformation Manager
Scope of Work:
The position of Gender Equality & Transformation Manager is key to CARE achieving its long range objective that disadvantaged and vulnerable women and girls are empowered and practice economic, political, social, civil and cultural rights by 2025. CARE will be working on economic empowerment, GBV and women’s voice as core areas within our programming amongst both Jordanian women as well as refugees The position will play a leading role to ensure high quality women’s empowerment and gender programming in CARE Jordan, lead on research, as well as supporting high level advocacy and networking on gender and women’s empowerment. The position will report to the Deputy Country Directors-Programs, and play a coordinating and advisory role on gender issues across all of our programming. The position is expected to bring in significant expertise in particularly GBV combating programming and Women’s political, economic and social participation; both amongst Jordanian women as well as refugee women (both Syrian and Iraqi and others)
 
Duties and Responsibilities:
 
Research & innovation:

Develop and implement research together with field teams which contributes to a deepened understanding of gender issues and women’s empowerment in Jordan, in particular around GBV, women’s voice and economic empowerment

 

Support project research, evaluations, and baseline studies on gender/women’s empowerment with technical advice and guidance

 

Keep abreast of relevant existing and new research in Jordan by other institutions that is related to women’s empowerment/gender issues; and disseminate key outcomes with field teams in appropriate and effective way

 

Work with field teams to review the quality and impact of our programming from a gender perspective
Work with field teams to develop and strengthen program strategies and approaches from a gender perspective

 

Ensure learning and innovation is reflected in CARE’s program strategy documents

 
 
Program design and Funds raising:
 

Support program design and grant development based on learning from existing programming, evaluations, research

 

To work with program directors and CO Senior Management Team to integrate good practices, building on the IASC Gender and Age Marker, the Minimum Standards on Gender and Age piloted in Cash, Protection, Livelihood and other sectors. All Proposals and Projects need to be evaluated based on the IASC Gender Marker to ensure that all CARE Projects are Gender sensitive, then responsive and to put a clear plan to strengthen these programs so it can be Gender Transformative.

 

Ensure interaction with our impact groups during program design

 

Facilitate consultations with field teams during project design, in collaboration with units heads of urban and camp programs

 

Support consultations with partners, government agencies and others in the preparation of new designs

 

Work with heads of unit and Deputy CD-P in the design of project proposal documents

 

Ensure all project proposals have been designed with gender sensitive approaches, and the needs of women, girls, boys and men have been clearly considered during the design.

 

Design a review/audit plan on all CO Programs situation, to come up with clear recommendations about areas of improvements. Communicate the findings to all SMT staffs and suggest a clear advices and provide staffs with clear gaudiness.

 
 
Technical support & training:
 

Agree with each Senior Management Team and Deputy-CD-P on a quarterly gender capacity building plan for each unit

 

Provide technical support to CARE programs and projects on mainstreaming gender sensitivity, GBV, women’s voice and economic empowerment in line with the plan

 

Provide targeted training to staff on key topics related to gender & women’s empowerment, in particular related to gender analysis, GBV, women’s voice and economic empowerment

 

Monitor progress against agreed indicators related to CARE’s capacity to implement gender sensitive and gender transformative programming and report this back to the

 

Work closely with CARE’s global gender / GBV advisors

 
 
Advocacy, coordination and networking:
 

In collaboration with CD, Deputy CD-P and program directors and managers develop advocacy strategies and messaging around gender/women’s empowerment based on CAREs research and programming, and play a lead role in coordinating their implementation

 

Build up a collaborative network of peers, government agencies and local NGOs engaged in issues related to gender/women’s empowerment and coordinate and collaborate on research, programming and advocacy

 

Represent CARE in relevant external fora, media and with other external stakeholders on gender issues

 

Develop communication materials to support our advocacy strategy as well as enhance CARE’s visibility in gender issues

 
 
Human resources:
 

Work with HR and program directors and managers to help ensure a good gender balance in each of our teams

 

Build capacity in gender sensitive programming, gender analysis

 

Support managers in helping ensure gender sensitivity amongst our teams in the way teams collaborate internally as well as how they work with beneficiaries.

 

Provide regular training to new staff on key CO policies, in particular the PSEA and Child Protection; in collaboration with the HR department

 
Emergency Response / Staff Security:
 

Take a lead role in facilitating timely, quality administrative support function delivery in the time of emergency response
Guides and supports management on staff security concerns
Ensure security operational guidelines well established for the CO and field offices following CARE USA Security Guidelines, and all staff are aware (in coordination with the CD)
Promote a safe and secure work environment; foster a safety and security culture; and ensure consistent application of, and compliance with, CARE Jordan –and the other organization’s- safety and security policies and procedures

Bachelor’s degree in a relevant field (Women’s Studies, Human Rights, Social Science, , Public Administration, Business Administration, Developmental Studies)


5-10 years of experience in gender programming, including significant experience on GBV, women’s voice and/or economic empowerment
Strong understanding of the Jordanian political and legal systems as related to women’s rights as well as demonstrated experience in working in/collaborating with civil society
Proven skills in partnership building, influencing and negotiation with a range of actors, including governments, UN agencies, academic institutions, networks, national/local NGOs and community groups
Strong analytical skills, and ability to design and direct research, needs assessments, and evaluations

Excellent interpersonal and communications skills

Outstanding organizational skills

Excellent interpersonal and communication skills (verbal and writing)
Strong team player skills and experienced collaborator

General Position Summary: 
The Monitoring, Evaluation, Accountability and Learning (MEAL) Manager is an important position in the Mercy Corps Jordan program responsible for providing oversight of country-level monitoring and evaluation (M&E) department staff, ensuring the quality of the portfolio’s M&E, and the timely delivery of M&E reporting to donors, as well as information management via Mercy Corps’s proprietary Tola systems, geographic information systems (GIS), and other such systems as the MEAL manager may design and implement. The MEAL Manager’s role is to oversee and ensure coordination of these technical areas across the M&E staff and programs. The MEAL Manager is also responsible for the capacity building and mentoring strategy for Mercy Corps Jordan staff on themes related to monitoring, evaluation, accountability, learning, and adaptive management. Accountability and learning is a strategic focus for Mercy Corps Jordan through the implementation of the Community Accountability and Response Mechanism (CARM) and supporting data-driven evidence based learning cycles.
The MEAL Manager is an integral part of Mercy Corps Jordan’s Impact Design and Learning (IDL) unit which aims to support programs to improve and amplify impact through informed design, evidence-based learning, and strategic research, communications and advocacy efforts. Key objectives of IDL are to build capacity, apply learning and fostering coordination between programs and project team members to reach country-level strategic goals.  This is done by training, proposal design, M&E team support, and linking to resources;  by internal and external communications efforts, supporting the development of policy papers and reports for dissemination to stakeholders at multiple levels; and via the development of intentional learning cycles to share lessons, resources and stakeholder relationships to streamline and improve program design, implementation, and impact for the communities we seek to support.
Essential Job Functions: 
Strategic Leadership and Accountability

Provide leadership, in collaboration with the Director of Programs and the Country Director, to M&E units distributed throughout the country office portfolio.
Ensure individual programs are effectively implementing required M&E systems and tools.
Consolidate program-level innovations and feedback, incorporating it into the broader country-level M&E system and country strategy.  
Using these approaches, systems, and tools, design and execute learning cycles and adaptive management protocols tailored to each country office project.
As a strategic leader, actively participate in management meetings and country-wide strategy sessions.
Oversee Mercy Corps Jordan’s multi-level Community Accountability and Reporting Mechanism (CARM).
Assist in the recruitment of skilled M&E program staff and organize the program teams to perform M&E activities.
Participate in internal and external MEAL-related working groups and maintain close working relationships with MEAL counterparts in other relevant international NGOs, local NGOs and associations in Jordan.
Be an active contributor and collaborator with regional and global counterparts to promote and learn the use of M&E and ICT best practices.
Define and execute an office-wide M&E agenda, with prioritized subjects of strategic assessment and evaluation.
Contribute to proposal writing and reviewing.

Monitoring, Evaluation, Learning and Information Management

With the Director of Programs and the entire IDL team, lead Mercy Corps Jordan in the setup and implementation of a holistic MEAL system that uses open source software and flexible cloud solutions to more accurately collect, monitor, verify and document program activities.
Contribute to program design, ensuring adherence to Mercy Corps’ M&E best practices and minimum standards, including the use of standardized indicators, form templates and documentation methodologies.
Lead and support Tola data management system roll-out, utilization, and learning across all Mercy Corps Jordan country programs.
Establish a data-visualization agenda that prioritizes and schedules the release of paper and digital products reflecting program activities and impact.
Ensure the accuracy and comprehensiveness of country-level reporting on indicators such as beneficiary numbers, design for impact indicators, 3RP, ActivityInfo and other information as needed.
Provide leadership in the development of a mobile data collection capability, as well as relational database design.

Capacity Building and Mentoring:

Develop and oversees implementation of the M&E staff and partner capacity-building strategy that promotes a culture of learning and adaptation through systematic analysis of program data.
Provide training and mentoring in the development of M&E plans, M&E tools as well as survey design, methodology, data collection and analysis and other skills as required for assessing the impact of programs.
Under the direction of the Director of Programs, support efforts to promote and share internal learning.
Work closely with Program Managers and Human Resources to ensure that M&E and ICT skills are incorporated in all program position descriptions.
Contribute to the knowledge management repository with best practices in M&E and ICT and ensure that it is accessible to all staff and partners.
Actively provide mentorship for all M&E staff including transparency and flexibility.

Supervisory Responsibility of: Program and project-level M&E staff
Reports Directly to: Director of Programs
Works Directly with: Impact Design and Learning Unit, Project Managers, Program Directors, Program Development and Quality Advisor, Country Director, Finance, and Operations.
Knowledge and Experience:

Undergraduate degree in development studies, research methods, statistics, economics, social sciences, monitoring and evaluation, project management or other relevant field required.  Post-graduate degree preferred. 
Minimum 5 years of experience in monitoring and evaluation with the proven use of database, data-visualization, project management, and other relevant IT platforms.
Excellent written English skills, with proven ability to produce final documents (such as logframes, AMEPs, etc.) for donor consumption
Preference given to candidates with prior management experience, particularly in design and execution of adaptive management strategies and protocols. 
Successful experience with the adoption of mobile data collections tools like Open Data Kit (ODK) and Ona including XLS Forms authoring.
Experience with theoretical and practical background in research or MEAL and knowledge of qualitative and quantitative methodologies and techniques required.
Knowledge of major aspects of program development, implementation and documentation and excellent verbal and written communication skills required.
Excellent quantitative skills and experience with Excel, Access, and statistical packages including Stata and/or SPSS, and GIS tools like QGIS, ArcGIS, and Google Earth Engine.
Experience with data management including the ability to structure and collate data sets for ease of analysis. 
Demonstrated understanding of intermediate statistics and ability to summarize and make predictions from multiple data sets.
Ability to conceptualize, plan and implement research activities creatively, as well as possess the ability to analyze data and utilize lessons learned for the continuous improvement of program implementation and to promote a culture of learning.
Proven ability to work productively with a variety of stakeholders to run participatory processes and meet tight deadlines with an emphasis on producing quality products.
Commitment to capacity building required. 
Actively promote communication, learning and accountability.
Fluency in spoken and written English as well as Arabic.

Success Factors: 
The successful candidate will have proven experience working with a cross-cultural team and possess strong capacity building and mentoring skills that promotes a culture of learning. They will demonstrate a strong commitment to teamwork and accountability, and make effective communication a priority in all situations. A sense of humor, team mentality and positive nature is highly desirable.

The ideal candidate will have demonstrated experience in field research and evaluation, preferably with expertise in working with communities and collecting survey data with children and families. Knowledge of education and/or child Development a plus.

• Inputtdata into tablets

• Paricitpate in the recap session.

Work Experience: Experience in delivering questionnaires and surveys in communities preferred, good communition skills, experience in education and/or child development preferred.

o Attend 3 days training

Epicentre recruits an Epidemiologist
based in Dubai (UAE)
Epicentre is a non-profit organization, created in 1986 by Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), whose activities cover research projects to assess health situations in complex environments, to evaluate health care programs, and to test new care strategies in field conditions. Epicentre is comprised of health professionals specialised in epidemiological methods. In 1996, Epicentre became a World Health Organization Collaborating Centre for Research in Epidemiology and Response to Emerging Diseases.
Under Epicentre’s Director of Intervention Epidemiology and Training, through the supervision of an Epicentre senior epidemiologist, in close and permanent collaboration with the Head of the MSF-Dubai cell and her deputies, the Epidemiologist :
 assists Médecins Sans Frontières field teams in the monitoring of health programs across the Middle East region and the health status of populations targeted by these programs.
 is responsible for the development and implementation of research projects within the programs run by the MSF’s Operational Cell in Dubai conducted with Médecins Sans Frontières.
 provides support to the cell to better frame and explore potential research questions through exploratory analyses of programmatic data.
 contributes to Epicentre’s regular activities such as representation in technical working groups, training and scientific communication.
Candidate requirements and desired competencies
 Medical Doctor (preferable) or Doctoral Degree, with a post-graduate degree in epidemiology (preferable), biostatistics or public health
 Previous relevant working experience with MSF and/or with another agency delivering humanitarian services.
 Willing to travel 3 to 4 months a year, sometimes at short notice and in insecure settings
 Fluent in English; fluency or working knowledge in Arabic and/or French strongly preferable
 Communicates effectively and clearly orally and in writing
 Writes well-structured, succinct and thoroughly referenced scientific reports and journal papers
 Uses his/her strong understanding of the public health features of crises to identify, appraise and synthesise available health information into an overall situation analysis to inform programmatic decisions
 Formulates appropriate research questions to investigate programmatic challenges, and identifies the most appropriate and feasible epidemiological study design to answer these
 Manages relations with important stakeholders across the organization to drive forward assessments and research studies, and effectively oversees ad hoc data collection teams

PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY:
Mercy Corps has been working hand-in-hand in Jordan with local communities and partners since 2002 to implement US, UN, EU, UK, and private donor funded projects. In 2006 Mercy Corps began implementation of a highly successful $30M USD Community Based Initiative for Water Demand Management (CBIWDM) project, which worked with 175 community-based organizations across Jordan to promote water demand management and energy saving and generating technologies. In addition, Mercy Corps is helping meet the immediate needs of vulnerable Syrian refugees in Jordan, supporting them and their Jordanian host communities to meet urgent and basic needs by developing and supporting short and medium-term economic opportunities while also improving the capacity of shared infrastructure and services, such as water systems, in order to serve an increased population. Mercy Corps now looks to start a new, multi-year USAID grant to build on lessons learned from 9 years of strong community development work in water resource management.
The Water Innovations Technology (WIT) project is a 5-year $35 million USAID-funded program designed to catalyze water conservation in Jordan. Jordan is the fifth most water poor country on earth and urgent action is required to make better use of existing water resources due to economic, population, and climate pressures. The WIT will contribute to the overall objective of conserving water in Jordan, through the adoption and proven water-saving technologies and techniques, by achieving three integrated outcomes: 1) Water conserving technologies and behavior changes are adopted at the agricultural, community and household levels; 2) Access to financing for adoption of water conservation technology is improved; and 3) Institutions strengthened to support water saving technologies.
RESPONSIBILITIES

Work with the Access to Finance & Private Partnerships Teams Leader in the design, planning and implementation of the activities according to the work plan, project document and implementation strategy. This includes preparation of annual work plans, and MEL updates.
Support Access to Finance & Private Partnerships Teams Leader as needed (making sure the project is on scope, budget, and time);
Develop and implement work plans focused on key outputs and outcomes;
Assist in establishing the grants administration process.
Assist the grants administration process including receiving, sorting and reviewing applications for eligibility and completeness.
Ensure all programming follows Mercy Corps’ internal systems and procedures
Work and coordinate with other Mercy Corps Projects working on the same areas to coordinate the work and get easy access to communities and community leaders
Establishment and maintenance of relationships with financing institutions both formal and informal.


Analyze the financing value chain of water conservation technology applications and identify collaboration and partnerships opportunities.
Map different financing mechanisms that would be appropriate to support different target groups.
Approach private sector companies to identify opportunities for financing under their CSR programs.
Raise the awareness of the formal financing institutions about potential clients from the water conservation sector.  
Facilitate linkages between target groups and financial institutions.  
Identify & report any success stories and case studies documentation, where applicable.


Support networking with relevant stakeholders. Foster and maintain connections and good relations
Ensure that there are fluent communication channels, and that the reporting schedule is timely met and that program objectives are achieved
Prepare field reports and contribute to progress reports as required.
Participate in establishing a comprehensive and an updated database for the project.
Work with local partners to collect and analyze data.
Help in submitting progress reports that related to Donor's reporting system, to include accurate number of beneficiaries, along with adequate analysis, recommendations and lessons learned.
Conduct regular monitoring visits to project locations.
Assist in organizing field visits for donors to project activities and prepare/provide programmatic and logistical support as needed.
Other duties as assigned.    

CRITICAL COMPETENCIES                                                   

Cross-functional expertise in business, project management, research and business development.
Office productivity in Windows, Microsoft Office Suite, Internet Applications.
Strong understanding of diversity.
Good interpersonal skills with people of all ages and backgrounds.
Ability to work under pressure, independently and with limited supervision
Demonstrated creative problem-solving skills
Security, political and cultural aware
Highly developed interpersonal communication skills

REQUIREMENT (KNOWLEDGE/SKILLS COMPETENCIES)

Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration ,financing or any related field.
At least 2-4 years practical experience in financing, grants, fundraising or partnerships..
Good knowledge of USAID grants Rules and Regulations is an advantage. Experience managing data sets.
Experience providing technical assistance and trainings to, as well as facilitating dialogue among, diverse groups.
Previous experience working on USAID-funded programs is desirable.
Strong skills in writing project reports. 
Fluency in English and Arabic.

SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITY: None  
REPORTS DIRECTLY TO: Private Partnerships Teams Leader
WORKS DIRECTLY WITH:  Mercy Corps WIT team

*DEFINITIONS:
Eligible Family Member (EFM): An EFM for employment purposes is an individual who meets all of
the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen or not a U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610); or
Child, who is unmarried and under 21 years of age or, regardless of age, is incapable of self-support;or
Parent (including stepparents and legally adoptive parents) of employee, spouse, or same-sex domestic partner, when such parent is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support; or
Sister or brother (including stepsisters and stepbrothers, or adoptive sisters or brothers) of the employee, spouse, or same-sex domestic partner when such sibling is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support, unmarried, and under 21 years of age, or regardless of age, incapable of self-support; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority.

EFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP. Two Exceptions: (a) EFMs without a U.S. Social Security Number are considered OR
and paid on the LCP; and (b) non-US citizen EFMs who are in the country of their birth/citizenship are considered
OR and paid on the LCP.
U.S. Citizen Eligible Family Member (USEFM): A USEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and resides at the sponsoring employee’s post of assignment abroad; and is under chief of mission authority; or
 resides at an Involuntary Separate Maintenance Allowance (ISMA) location authorized under 3 FAM 3232.2; or
Currently receives a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

USEFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP. Two Exceptions: (a) USEFMs residing at an ISMA location are considered OR and
are paid on the LCP; in this case, the USEFM would need to obtain his/her own residency and work permit as
required by the host country; and (b) dual-national USEFMs who are in the country of their birth/citizenship may be
considered OR and paid on the LCP depending on host country labor law.
Appointment Eligible Family Member (AEFM): An AEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority; and
Is residing at the sponsoring employee's post of assignment abroad; and
Does NOT currently receive a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

AEFMs are considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule,
not under the LCP.
Member of Household (MOH) – An individual who accompanies or joins a sponsoring employee, i.e.,
sponsor is a direct hire employee under Chief of Mission authority, either Foreign Service, Civil Service,
or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad at a U.S. mission. A
MOH is an individual who meets the following criteria: 
(1) Not an EFM and therefore not on the travel orders or approved through form OF-126 Foreign Service
Residence and Dependency Report of the sponsoring employee; and
(2) Officially declared by the sponsoring U.S. Government employee to the Chief of Mission (COM) as
part of his or her household and approved by the COM; and
(3) Is a parent, grandparent, grandchild, unmarried partner, adult child, foreign born child in the process
of being adopted, father, mother, brother, sister, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughterin-law,
brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother,
stepsister, half-brother, or half-sister who falls outside the Department’s current definition of Eligible
Family Member 14 FAM 511.3. A MOH may or may not be a U.S. Citizen.
MOHs do not receive a hiring preference. However, if a position is advertised as “Open to: Current Employees of
the Mission”, MOHs who are not currently employed in the mission are eligible to apply. MOHs are hired on
Personal Services Agreements (PSAs).
Not Ordinarily Resident (NOR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

An EFM, USEFM or AEFM of a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member permanently assigned or stationed abroad; or
Has diplomatic privileges and immunities; and
Is eligible for compensation under the FS or GS salary schedule; and
Has a U.S. Social Security Number (SSN); and
Is not a citizen of the host country; and
Does not ordinarily reside in the host country; and
Is not subject to host country employment and tax laws.

NORs are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule, not under the LCP.
Ordinarily Resident (OR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

A citizen of the host country; or
A non-citizen of the host country (including a U.S. citizen or a third-country national) who is locally resident and has legal and/or permanent resident status within the host country and/or who is a holder of a non-diplomatic visa/work and/or residency permit; and/or
Is subject to host country employment and tax laws.

ORs (including U.S. citizen ORs) are compensated in accordance with the Local Compensation Plan (LCP). U.S.
citizen ORs are entitled to a U.S. minimum wage supplement if their salary does not meet or exceed the current U.S.

JOB SUMMARY:
Since September 2014, CARE has been running a remotely-managed program in Southern Syria. The strategic focus has been on gender-sensitive WASH, livelihoods and rapid response programming. CARE is now expanding into community-based protection services, with approaches to psycho-social support programming for Southern Syria now being developed and piloted with OFDA funding. CARE is seeking a gender and protection advisor to provide technical support to this project, as well as to the broader South and Central Syria program, including support on strengthening PSEA policy and processes. As the cross-border program continues to rapidly expand, the position will play a leading role in setting up systems and processes to ensure high quality integration of gender and protection in programming and partnerships; raising the profile of CARE as a partner in gender and protection related activities and advocacy; managing CARE South and Central Syria gender and protection efforts from development to implementation including producing issue analysis, policy proposals, campaign messages and strategies, and action alerts and building capacity .
 
RESPONSIBILITIES AND TASKS:
 

Strengthening Protection Programming 

To contribute to the development of strategic and tactical program/project plans with particular emphasis on gender and protection, ensuring the commitment of all stakeholders and steady accomplishment of CARE’s objectives. Including but not limited to:
 
Subtasks

Supporting the design and implementation of gender and protection programing, including the development of technically sound and contextually psycho-social support group curricula
Providing daily technical guidance and capacity building support to Deputy Protection Manager
Supporting protection team to adapt existing tools and develop new tools for partners to implement protection programing, including adaptation and training on use of information volunteers programming used in other CARE programs
Supporting protection teams to develop trainings and orientations for partners on use of tools and approaches
Ensuring protection team equipped with necessary tools and knowledge to effectively implement their programs
Engaging with protection and MEAL teams to develop appropriate M&E plans for protection activities
Keeping up to date with best practices in gender and protection in order to act as an expert; providing advice and guidance as required
Supporting the regular collection and analysis of complete and up-to-date gender and protection information needed for effective program/project design and monitoring
Reviewing program documents and participating in situation analysis; and contributing to the development of the overall program strategic plan
Ensuring alignment of gender and protection plans with CARE global strategy but in particular Syria strategy and objectives

 

Provide CARE staff and partners with technical advice & support

To provide South and Central Syria Team and partners with gender and protection related technical advice and support, enabling them to deliver agreed plans and sustainably operate according to best practices

Identifying staff capacity gaps in gender and protection both in country and other operational locations and building their capacity on technical gender and protection issues and initiatives
Working closely with Partnerships Coordinator and Program Managers, contributing to partner capacity assessments to identify partner capacity gaps in gender and, and develop trainings and tools to strengthen partner capacity in specific and targeted ways
Providing information and relevant reading materials (gender and protection related) to staff and partners
With Partnerships Coordinator, developing and maintaining an updated comprehensive database of partners involved in gender and protection work and collaborating agencies (profiles and track of capacity building offered and partnership status, etc).


Continuously improving personal capacity to operate according to best practices in gender and protection
Keeping alert to Staff and partners needs for assistance, for example:
	
Carrying out spot checks
Organizing and/or attending review & learning meetings
Reviewing monitoring information and reports
Gathering feedback from wider stakeholders
Responding to requests for assistance


Taking the initiative to contact Staff and partners in order to make an intervention, for example:
	
Offering advice
Coaching/mentoring
Demonstrating best practice
Setting up or adjusting systems
Providing methodologies and approaches
Setting up exchange visits where possible


As requested by Deputy Program Director and Program/Project Managers/Partnerships Coordinator, offering the above technical advice and support to Partners; especially if interventions have been articulated in partner capacity building plans

 

Lead on gender and protection mainstreaming for CARE’s South and Central Syria program

To lead the Program Team in developing/reviewing and implementing gender and protection initiatives and plans, aiming to bring about social change and poverty alleviation for vulnerable groups

Engaging closely with Program Managers to understand gender/protection concerns within programs, and identify concrete recommendations for ways to strengthen gender/protection mainstreaming within those programs
Leading on updating of Gender Action Plan for South and Central Syria
Leading a basic program self-assessment of gender sensitivity, and developing behaviour change targets for CARE staff and partners (through an outcome mapping process establishing progress markers for the CARE team and partners).
Developing and monitoring a set of agreed gender and protection mainstreaming minimum standards, adapted for remote management in Syria context
Providing training on Do No Harm Principles

 

Lead on strengthening and adapting CARE’s PSEA policy and processes for programming inside Syria, including: 

To work with Program Teams and Partners to identify and clarify key activity areas, initiatives and communication channels that will enhance the implementation of CARE’s PSEA policy and processes inside Syria. Including but not limited to:

Mapping existing PSEA initiatives in southern and central Syria
Developing a PSEA strategy and action plan for CARE’s programming in southern and central Syria.


Developing communication materials with PSEA messages and appropriate communication channels in Syria
Assessing the extent to which program teams and partners complies with PSEA messages and taking appropriate actions to ensure we practice what we preach [leading by example]
Being alert to current PSEA policy debates [local, regional and international] and taking the initiative to participate or contribute and alert staff and partners to these developments
Participating in the researching and/or collecting and analysing data in order to fully understand the root causes of problems and identify issues for action; ensuring that chosen issues are aligned to CARE policies and priorities

University Research Co., LLC (URC)
URC is a global company dedicated to improving the quality of health care, social services, and health education worldwide. With a non-profit affiliate, the Center for Human Services (CHS), URC manages projects in over 45 countries, including the United States.
Established in 1965, URC offers a range of technical assistance to strengthen health and social systems and service quality by empowering communities and health workers to identify and scale up locally appropriate solutions to critical problems. Internationally, we expand access to and improve the quality of services addressing maternal, newborn, and child health; infectious diseases, including HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria; reproductive health and family planning; food and nutrition; and vulnerable children and families. In the US, we focus on improving communication related to issues like substance abuse, with a particular focus on reaching underserved populations.
URC’s mission is to provide innovative, evidence-based solutions to health and social challenges worldwide. Please join us in carrying out our mission (http://www.urc-chs.com/).
Project Description: 
As a global cooperative agreement, HRH2030 supports USAID/Washington and field missions in strengthening human resources for health (HRH) across 42 priority countries to increase the accessibility, availability, acceptability, and quality of the health workforce needed to improve health outcomes and advance universal health coverage. HRH2030 is designed to 1) increase performance and productivity of the health workforce, 2) increase the number, skill mix, and competency of the health workforce, 3) strengthen HRH/HSS leadership and governance capacity and, 4) increase the sustainability of investment in the health workforce. URC is a sub-awardee to Chemonics International as the prime implementing partner, HR.
In support of Jordan’s Ministry of Health (MOH) Strategic Plan 2013-2017 Objective #5 to “Deploy and manage human resources efficiently and effectively,” and the Jordan Vision 2025 aim of achieving universal health coverage for all Jordanians, USAID/Jordan seeks to strengthen national public-sector HRH systems through a robust, targeted set of activities strategically linked to achieve the following goal: Strengthened health workforce for better health services. This goal will be realized through the attainment of three main objectives:

Improved Human Resources Practices at the Ministry of Health by strengthening human resources systems and staff capacity to efficiently and effectively motivate, retain, and distribute the workforce.
Improved Health Workforce Competency by training emerging health leaders and supervisors and supporting a national continuing professional development system for the health workforce. 
Strengthened National HRH Governance by improving national HRH policies and strategic plans and improving HRH data for decision-making.

Interventions to achieve these three objectives will be aimed at all levels of the health system: the central MOH level, the de-centralized MOH directorates at the governorate level, and the national HRH governance level.

The Learning and Development Technical Advisor reports to the HRH2030 Project Director in Jordan and is directly responsible for providing a broad range of technical direction to the activity’s cross-cutting learning interventions to accomplish all three results. Specifically, the Learning and Development Technical Advisor will work with the component leads and stakeholders to engage in assessing learning needs, developing curricula and materials to meet those needs, and ensure successful delivery of courses to build MOH HRH capacity.

Work with HRH2030’s component leads to identify learning needs for activity interventions and coordinate all curriculum development and execution.
Provide technical assistance in developing, coordinating, and ensuring delivery of courses related to HRH2030 activities, including but not limited to human resource management and development, MOH leadership, health facility management and leadership, HRH data collection, human resource information systems, workforce indicator of staffing needs, and national health workforce accounts.
Create and/or refine curricula, materials, and technical assignments in collaboration with component leads and other stakeholders.
Provide technical assistance, such as assessments, training resource development, and oversight, to promote supportive supervision as an accepted and practiced management style at the health directorates and flowed down to MOH health facilities.

Background/IRC Summary:  The International Rescue Committee (IRC) responds to the world's worst humanitarian crises and helps people to survive and rebuild their lives. Founded in 1933 at the request of Albert Einstein, the IRC offers lifesaving care and life-changing assistance to refugees forced to flee from war or disaster. At work today in over 40 countries and 26 U.S. cities, we restore safety, dignity and hope to millions who are uprooted and struggling to endure.
The IRC Jordan program was established in 2007 and is currently operating programs in Jordan and southern Syria with an annual budget of $36 million; approximately $25 million is for southern Syria. Background
The Jordan Health Finance and Governance (HFG) is an activity funded by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID). It aims to improve health sector sustainability and resiliency in Jordan. HFG’s goal supports Jordan’s commitment to universal health coverage declared in the Jordan National Health Strategy 2016-2020 “…to provide health, financial, and social protection to the entire population on a fair basis.”  
The HFG mission is to work with the Jordanian government and other stakeholders to strengthen health system advances in efficiency, capabilities, and governance supporting improved health status for the population of Jordan.  Increasing the demand for and use of high-quality, transparently available data, especially the micro-level data necessary for operations management and to inform decision making and monitoring in the health sector of Jordan, is one of the objectives of HFG.  In addition, HFG needs micro-level data to complete workplan tasks including efficiency and cost studies, actuarial analysis, performance reviews, and evaluation of sector transparency to civil society.
To support HFG objectives and work tasks, the consultant will review the entire life cycle of required micro-level data, described below, in the significant health finance and delivery organizations of the public and private sectors. The life cycle encompasses business and operations data requirements; data capture and collection; data storage, organization, maintenance and archiving; data quality; and data ownership, security, access and availability.  The consultant will examine micro-level data that records pertinent details about health insurance and care transactions for individual consumers.  Typically, this type of information comes from insurance records and electronic medical records (EMRs)/charts.  HFG must understand Jordan’s current ability to collect disaggregate data about individual users and providers and analyze them. 
Micro-level Data for Health Finance and Services Operations and Management
Critical to effective health services management is the ability to link health care transaction cost and use information to the individual who receives the service, to the provider who delivers the service, and to the insurer, if there is one, who pays for the service.   
Health Care Services- EMRs/charts typically record information about the services delivered by providers to consumers.  At a minimum information is needed to uniquely identify the patient, their medical conditions/diagnoses, the number and types of procedures delivered, the presiding provider, the amount billed and paid for the services if those amounts are not the same. There should be use of ICD10 and standard procedure codes.  
Providers-  Each health care service delivered needs to be linked to the individual provider of record who delivered it, as well as the clinic, facility, pharmacy, etc. where it was delivered.  Unique provider IDs should allow analysts to link to important information about the provider such as location, specialty, licensure or certification status, years in practice, etc.  
Consumer/Patient/Member- Each healthcare service delivered needs to be linked to the individual who received it.  Unique person identifiers should allow analysts to link to important demographic and social information about the individual- insurance status, age, gender, location, employment, income level, marital status and dependents, health status/complexity.  This information may be housed in various places, possibly even outside the health sector. 
In addition to healthcare users, health sector managers must also understand those who do not use the health care system.  Therefore, it is important to be able to identify those who do not use services and examine their demographic and social characteristics. 
Consultant Responsibilities/Scope of Work
The consultant will:

Propose major public and private health sector organizations to be included in the data review.  There should be insurance organizations and healthcare delivery entities of various types (primary, secondary, tertiary, pharmacies, etc.).  This SOW will be completed by examining the data environment in each insurer and provider specified.
Identify healthcare insurance and delivery data requirements (transaction data elements that should be captured) about consumers, providers, insurers, and services. Give special consideration to data required to complete the following HFG tasks.  Note, the consultant is to assess the data availability for completing the studies, not conduct them.
Cost and Use Studies- Examine the allocation (use and costs) of resources among different types of providers and health care services such as primary care, prevention, curative care, geriatric care, secondary care, tertiary care, emergency services, different types of medications, and specific diagnoses and procedures.  Examine the demographic and social characteristics of those who use and do not use health care services such as age, gender, insurance coverage, employment, income, and household size.  Link services, users, and providers. Consider the cost effectiveness of the mix of services and the alignment of services with provider availability and population needs and wants. 
Actuarial Studies- There is need for actuarially sound premium options for current public insurance schemes, in their current and other possible configurations. Determine current or expected costs of care and various premium options for various levels of cost recovery, illustrating the tradeoffs between the pocketbooks of households and the government’s budget. Cost and use data about different categories of health care services associated with different member and provider groups, typically age-gender, are required.
Government Transparency - Jordan is a member of the Open Government Partnership that promotes transparency, e-government and calls for improved information disclosure. In addition, the new decentralization law requires wider participation of communities in governance.  The extent of transparency and effective civil society participation in health sector governance is correlated with access to meaningful information that meets community needs.
Performance - Useful performance indicators require micro level data that describes how performers, both groups and individuals, behave.  To be beneficial, performance metrics such as KPIs need to be able to isolate and discriminate between strong and poor performers.  Micro data is needed in provider and insurer organizations.
Identify existing data sources.  What is tracked regularly when the insurance or delivery system is used?  Which data elements are captured and how are they stored?   Create a map showing where data are.
Determine whether existing data are complete and of sufficient quality to be useful.  How is quality assured at each step of the data process?  Is it possible to connect to other data bases containing more details about the consumers or providers (implies commonly used unique IDs)?  
Assess and document barriers to access to existing data.  Make suggestions for improvement.
Identify data gaps, prioritize them, and, to the extent possible, explain why the data are not collected.  Consider structural, political, and technical causes.
Present the most viable options for closing critical gaps including the feasibility of temporary work arounds and permanent remediation.
Propose interventions that remedy data deficiencies such as developing capacity, developing systems, identifying or modifying key data elements, and updating standard operating procedures for data collection and periodic reporting. Assess technical capabilities of staff at various institutions.  Consider IT architectural improvements such as need for a more comprehensive and integrated data warehouse.
Prepare a final report including a data map showing the organizations studied and the data owned; barriers and gaps that exist, and proposed short-term, mid-term and long-term changes.
Deliver a presentation to HFG stakeholders.

Requirements

The goal of the Remote Capacity Strengthening in Syria for Better Child Protection (RISE) project is to support the growth of a sustainable and active civil society in Syria capable of supporting humanitarian needs in the short term and eventually to recovery and reconstruction efforts. The three-year project builds on Save the Children’s (SCI) experience of providing humanitarian relief inside Syria while strengthening Syrian organizations’ organizational and technical capacities to respond to the needs of conflict-affected populations since the start of the conflict. 
The project focuses on strengthening, programmatic, management and operational skills of Syrian organizations, through a holistic capacity strengthening approach tailored to address the specific needs of partners; including through remote capacity strengthening methodologies.The project also aims at enhancing Child Protection programmatic technical capacities of Syrian organizations through the development and roll out of Child protection capacity strengthening resources contextualized for Syria.  Our approach includes access to funding to partner organizations as part of the capacity strengthening journey.  Funding supports partners to access capacity strengthening support beyond that offered by SCI, and access to grants gives partners the opportunity to gain practical experience through responding to protection needs of crisis-affected children. 
This project was designed to mitigate challenges local partners face accessing support to improve their humanitarian response capacities.  These challenges include increased travel restrictions for Syrian partner staff to travel to neighboring countries for face to face training, limited internet access inside Syria hindering access to resources, and limited opportunities for partner field staff – staff responsible for implementation – to access capacity strengthening support. 
The project is implemented across 4 access points programming in Syria from Jordan, Lebanon, Turkey and Iraq/NE Syria and is funded by the IKEA Foundation and the OAK Foundation. 
1.PURPOSE OF THE MIDTERM EVALUATION
The purpose of the midterm evaluation is to document the progress achieved to date and to provide an independent assessment of the effectiveness and relevance of the RISE project.
The midterm evaluation should take stock on key successes and good practices and challenges as well as give concrete recommendations.  Findings will primarily be used inform SCI project team to make decisions on which of our capacity strengthening interventions need to be adapted for the remainder of the RISE project.  As well as, explore piloting other capacity support interventions for partners.  Existing capacity support interventions under the RISE project include learning grants, coaching, face to face training, remote training through webinars, training through a third party, distance e-learning, capacity strengthening grants, and organizational development support for strategic partners. 
Findings will also be used by SCIto develop case studies based on key successes and good practices from the mid-term evaluation.
Both the evaluation and case studies will be shared with other SCI stakeholders involved in remote capacity strengthening programming.   
2.EVALUATION KEY QUESTIONS
The overall objective of the midterm evaluation is to assess to what degree Save the Children’s capacity strengthening support to civil society organizations we partner with inside Syria is appropriate. The Midterm evaluation will look at the overall capacity strengthening approach and specific interventions used to support partner organizations under the RISE project to assess relevance and appropriateness. The evaluation will identify and analyze factors that contributed to results/ lack of results, in order to help the implementing organizations and SCI adapt and revise the intervention strategies.
2.1 Participation
•How participatory do the partners find that the approach has been during the course of the project (from assessing needs, to planning interventions and carrying out interventions and evaluating them)? 
•To what extent do SC staff find that the approach has been managed in a participatory manner?
•To what extent has SC been responsive to feedback on the approach?
2.2 Relevance
Measuring to what extent the interventions are suited to the priorities of the target group (partners)
•To what extent are the objectives of the programme still valid?
•Do partners and SC staff find that the activities and outputs of the programme are consistent with the intended impacts and effects?
•How relevant do the partners find that the project is in relation to their capacity needs? 
2.3 Effectiveness
Measuring the extent to which an activity attains its objectives. It is measuring to what extent the objectives are achieved or likely to be achieved?
•To what extent do partners and SC staff find that the approach, methods, and tools are appropriate and in line with partners capacity needs? 
-Project and capacity strengthening approach
-Assessment tools
-Planning tools and workshops
-Monitoring and evaluation tools
2.4 Sustainability
Sustainability is concerned with measuring whether the benefits of an activity are likely to continue after donor funding has been withdrawn. 
•To what extent are the interventions implemented so far likely to contribute to sustainability and partners’ independence? 
Documents to be reviewed:
-Project proposal
-Save the Children’s Capacity Strengthening Approach for Syria
-Guidance on capacity strengthening process
-Guidance on CP capacity strengthening process
-Guidance for evaluating partners learning grants
-Workshop documents
-Partnership assessment
-Organizational capacity development assessment
-Thematic (Child Protection) capacity assessment 
-Capacity Strengthening and Monitoring plan templates
-Evaluations of CB interventions
-Other docs 
3.SCOPE OF THE EVALUATION AND METHODOLOGY
The midterm evaluation will cover the period of December 15, 2015 – June 14, 2017
The consultant will further develop the approach and methodology to respond to these terms of reference, in consultation with a SCI evaluation steering group as part of the inception report. The methodology is expected to be a participatory evaluation and the evaluator is expected to use a variety of participatory methods as interviews to collect both qualitative and quantitative data.
The key methods will include, but not limited to:
The literature review of existing documents such as the annual report of Year 1, MEAL plan and KPI table, Work Plan, various Guidance Notes for SCI Project Teams, Findings from the Learning Evaluations, Capacity Strengthening Approach Document, Partner Satisfaction Survey results, Partner Reports.
Interviews with key project staff and partner staff benefiting from the project interventions.
Report writing and debriefing with project team.
The evaluator has to take into account the guiding principles mentioned in the SCI Evaluation Handbook and work in accordance with SCI’s Child Safeguarding Principles.   
4.ORGANISATION, ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES
This is an external evaluation commissioned by SCI. The consultant will be responsible for the deliverables outlined below. The consultant will also be responsible for developing a sound evaluation methodology, planning and conducting a consultative review, managing the data collection, undertaking a thorough analysis of the data collected in order to write the report and present the findings and recommendations.
SCEvaluation steering group, and the evaluation manager will be responsible for facilitating the review process by providing relevant documents, facilitating introductions with SCI and partner staff from the 4 access points, covering all mid-term evaluation costs.  The steering group will conduct the final sign-off of the deliverables.
