*DEFINITIONS:
Eligible Family Member (EFM): An EFM for employment purposes is an individual who meets all of
the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen or not a U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610); or
Child, who is unmarried and under 21 years of age or, regardless of age, is incapable of self-support; or
Parent (including stepparents and legally adoptive parents) of employee, spouse, or same-sex  domestic partner, when such parent is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support; or
Sister or brother (including stepsisters and stepbrothers, or adoptive sisters or brothers) of the  employee, spouse, or same-sex domestic partner when such sibling is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support, unmarried, and under 21 years of age, or regardless of age, incapable of self-support; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority.

EFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP. Two Exceptions: (a) EFMs without a U.S. Social Security Number are considered OR
and paid on the LCP; and (b) non-US citizen EFMs who are in the country of their birth/citizenship are considered
OR and paid on the LCP.
U.S. Citizen Eligible Family Member (USEFM): A USEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and resides at the sponsoring employee’s post of assignment abroad; and is under chief of mission authority; or resides at an Involuntary Separate Maintenance Allowance (ISMA) location authorized under 3 FAM 3232.2; or
Currently receives a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

USEFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP.
Appointment Eligible Family Member (AEFM): An AEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority; and
Is residing at the sponsoring employee's post of assignment abroad; and
Does NOT currently receive a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

AEFMs are considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule,
not under the LCP.
Member of Household (MOH) – An individual who accompanies or joins a sponsoring employee, i.e.,
sponsor is a direct hire employee under Chief of Mission authority, either Foreign Service, Civil Service,
or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad at a U.S. mission. A
MOH is an individual who meets the following criteria:

Not an EFM and therefore not on the travel orders or approved through form OF-126 Foreign Service Residence and Dependency Report of the sponsoring employee; and
Officially declared by the sponsoring U.S. Government employee to the Chief of Mission (COM) as part of his or her household and approved by the COM; and
Is a parent, grandparent, grandchild, unmarried partner, adult child, foreign born child in the process of being adopted, father, mother, brother, sister, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughterin-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half-brother, or half-sister who falls outside the Department’s current definition of Eligible Family Member 14 FAM 511.3. A MOH may or may not be a U.S. Citizen.

MOHs are hired on Personal Services Agreements (PSAs).
Not Ordinarily Resident (NOR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

An EFM, USEFM or AEFM of a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member permanently assigned or stationed abroad; or
Has diplomatic privileges and immunities; and
Is eligible for compensation under the FS or GS salary schedule; and
Has a U.S. Social Security Number (SSN); and
Is not a citizen of the host country; and
Does not ordinarily reside in the host country; and
Is not subject to host country employment and tax laws.

NORs are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule, not under the LCP.
Ordinarily Resident (OR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

A citizen of the host country; or
A non-citizen of the host country (including a U.S. citizen or a third-country national) who is locally resident and has legal and/or permanent resident status within the host country and/or who is a holder of a non-diplomatic visa/work and/or residency permit; and/or
Is subject to host country employment and tax laws.

ORs (including U.S. citizen ORs) are compensated in accordance with the Local Compensation Plan (LCP).

Program Summary
The goal of USAID CEP is to leave behind stronger, more cohesive and resilient partner
communities in Irbid, Mafraq, Tafileh, and Ma’an. This goal will be achieved by working through,
and building the capacity of, Community Enhancement Teams (CETs), municipalities/local
governments, and Community Based Organizations (CBOs) as key stakeholders to:

Engage in a continuous, conflict-sensitive participatory process of identification and prioritization of stressors;
Develop immediate and long-term solutions by accessing available resources through collaboration and partnerships with relevant stakeholders (including, when appropriate, informal leaders); and,
Utilize effective and transparent communication mechanisms in support of increased community cohesion.

USAID CEP uses a transparent mobilization process as the entry point into partner
communities, conducting household perception surveys and facilitating community-wide
meetings to identify key stressors facing communities and form a Community Enhancement
Team (CET). Throughout the life of the program, the CET serves not only as a key stakeholder,
but also as USAID CEP’s primary counterpart. To affect the necessary behavior change to
achieve the intended goal of leaving behind stronger, more resilient communities, USAID CEP
implements three sets of integrated activities:

Community Engagement: Working closely with the CETs, USAID CEP facilitates the design and implementation of solutions for prioritized community-identified stressors.
Networking: Networking activities are designed to strengthen the key stakeholders’ ability to form partnerships, mobilize additional resources, share experiences, and strengthen intracommunity cohesion.
Conflict Management and Mitigation (CMM): To ensure that key stakeholders are equipped to operate in a fluid, complex environment and can effectively respond to emerging challenges, USAID CEP incorporates basic CMM training and offers a response mechanism to shocks and emerging stressors.

Office (PSO). The incumbent applies a comprehensive knowledge of protection techniques and
security practices to coordinate and implement protection for the Chief of Mission (COM),
high-ranking visiting dignitaries and COM personnel traveling to high-threat areas.

application for eligibility purposes.

*DEFINITIONS:
Eligible Family Member (EFM): An EFM for employment purposes is an individual who meets all of
the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen or not a U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610); or
Child, who is unmarried and under 21 years of age or, regardless of age, is incapable of self-support; or
 Parent (including stepparents and legally adoptive parents) of employee, spouse, or same-sex  domestic partner, when such parent is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support; or
Sister or brother (including stepsisters and stepbrothers, or adoptive sisters or brothers) of the  employee, spouse, or same-sex domestic partner when such sibling is at least 51 percent dependent on the employee for support, unmarried, and under 21 years of age, or regardless of age, incapable of self-support; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority.

EFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP. Two Exceptions: (a) EFMs without a U.S. Social Security Number are considered OR
and paid on the LCP; and (b) non-US citizen EFMs who are in the country of their birth/citizenship are considered
OR and paid on the LCP.
U.S. Citizen Eligible Family Member (USEFM): A USEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and resides at the sponsoring employee’s post of assignment abroad; and is under chief of mission authority; or
resides at an Involuntary Separate Maintenance Allowance (ISMA) location authorized under 3 FAM 3232.2; or
Currently receives a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

USEFMs are generally considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary
schedule, not under the LCP. Two Exceptions: (a) USEFMs residing at an ISMA location are considered OR and
are paid on the LCP; in this case, the USEFM would need to obtain his/her ownresidency and work permit as
required by the hostcountry; and (b) dual-national USEFMs who are in the country of their birth/citizenship may be
considered OR and paid on the LCP depending on host country labor law.
Appointment Eligible Family Member (AEFM): An AEFM for employment purposes is an individual
who meets all of the following criteria:

U.S. Citizen; and
Spouse or same-sex domestic partner (as defined in 3 FAM 1610) of the sponsoring employee; or
Child of the sponsoring employee who is unmarried and at least 18 years old; and
Listed on the travel orders or approved Form OF-126 of a sponsoring employee, i.e., a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad; and
Is under chief of mission authority; and
Is residing at the sponsoring employee's post of assignment abroad; and
Does NOT currently receive a U.S. Government retirement annuity or pension from a career in the U.S. Foreign Service or Civil Service.

AEFMs are considered Not-Ordinarily Resident (NOR) and are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule,
not under the LCP.
Member of Household (MOH) – An individual who accompanies or joins a sponsoring employee, i.e.,
sponsor is a direct hire employee under Chief of Mission authority, either Foreign Service, Civil Service,
or uniformed service member who is permanently assigned to or stationed abroad at a U.S. mission. A
MOH is an individual who meets the following criteria:
(1) Not an EFM and therefore not on the travel orders or approved through form OF-126 Foreign Service
Residence and Dependency Report of the sponsoring employee; and
(2) Officially declared by the sponsoring U.S. Government employee to the Chief of Mission (COM) as
part of his or her household and approved by the COM; and
(3) Is a parent, grandparent, grandchild, unmarried partner, adult child, foreign born child in the process
of being adopted, father, mother, brother, sister, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughterin-law,
brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother,
stepsister, half-brother, or half-sister who falls outside the Department’s current definition of Eligible
Family Member 14 FAM 511.3. A MOH may or may not be a U.S. Citizen.
MOHs do not receive a hiring preference. However, if a position is advertised as “Open to: Current Employees of
the Mission”,MOHs who are not currently employed in the mission are eligible to apply. MOHs are hired on
Personal Services Agreements (PSAs).
Not Ordinarily Resident (NOR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

An EFM, USEFM or AEFM of a direct-hire Foreign Service, Civil Service, or uniformed service member permanently assigned or stationed abroad; or
Has diplomatic privileges and immunities; and
Is eligible for compensation under the FS or GS salary schedule; and
Has a U.S. Social Security Number (SSN); and
Is not a citizen of the host country; and
Does not ordinarily reside in the host country; and
Is not subject to host country employment and tax laws.

NORs are compensated under the FS or GS salary schedule, not under the LCP.
Ordinarily Resident (OR) – An individual who meets the following criteria:

A citizen of the host country; or
A non-citizen of the host country (including a U.S. citizen or a third-country national) who is locally resident and has legal and/or permanent resident status within the host country and/or who is a holder of a non-diplomatic visa/work and/or residency permit; and/or
Is subject to host country employment and tax laws.

ORs (including U.S. citizen ORs) are compensated in accordance with the Local Compensation Plan (LCP). U.S.
citizen ORs are entitled to a U.S. minimum wage supplement if their salary does not meet or exceed the current U.S.
minimum wage.)

Job title:Logistic & Security Coordinator 
Location:Amman (with field movements)
Supervisor:Country Representative
Terre des hommes Lausanne  (Tdh-Lausanne) has been working in Jordan since 2007, starting its intervention with the Iraqi refugees, carrying out projects related to child protection (CP), psychosocial support (PSS), and then juvenile justice (JJ) in 2011. Since April 2012, Tdh has been intervening in the northern host communities, and since April 2013, in the Marjeeb al-Fahrood/Emirati Jordanian Camp (EJC). The aim is to support children and their families affected by the Syrian crisis and to strengthen the CP mechanisms in the camp and hosting communities.
Since the start of the crisis in Syria in March 2011 and following a continuous deterioration of the humanitarian situation, more than 640,000 people have sought refuge in Jordan. 
            
General Responsibilities and Principles
With the support and under the supervision of CR, the Logistics & Security coordinator’s mission is to ensure the efficient day-to-day logistics running of the different Tdh projects & offices in Jordan and ensure the security and safety of the staff in their work premises and ensures the provision and setting up of necessary equipment. As key person in the supply chain, the Logistics and Security Coordinator is in charge of purchasing supplies and managing the stock-taking and inventory follow-up. 
The incumbent commits to observe discretion on any information related to the organization functioning.
The incumbent will conduct his or her duties in respect of the Charter of Terre des hommes (Tdh) and Tdh Safeguarding Policy. 
The incumbent commits to ensure high level of children participation and will always work in the best interest of the child.
Tdh intervenes without any affiliation for politics, religion or financial profit. The incumbent will direct his or her activities and engagements without preoccupation of political, racial or religious affiliation.
Tdh expects that its staff and contractors’ professional conduct reflect proper behavior in accordance with local culture and traditions. The incumbent assures the moral protection of the name of Tdh and defends in all circumstances the interests of the movement.
Specific Responsibilities
Line Management
•Report to the CR.
•Supervise Logistics & Security Officer and Driver/Logistics Clerk.
Logistics     
•Manage buildings and installation: Locate possible buildings for rent when needed and ensure Installation and management of buildings in projects outside Amman is properly done.
•Organize and supervise the maintenance works in the premises.
•Ensure vehicles management is in order.
•Ensure vehicle fleet management (ensure all repairs and maintenance are carried on by the rental company) and make sure that the drivers fully comply with the Tdh transport procedures (including regular mechanic and equipment checking, Log sheet filling and so on).
•Make sure that proper filing and archiving of the logistics documents (fuel, car rental, copies of all procurement process, etc.) is in place.
•Organize & follow-up of the trips carried out by external means (Taxi, bus for activities, etc.).
•Organize trainings and external events in Jordan (hall rental, hotel booking, organizing transportation, etc.).
•Organize and supervise the maintenance works in the premises.
•Participate in the logistics organizing of project activities when needed (excursions for children, etc.)
Equipment and material management    
•Manage the installation of material and equipment in the premises.
•Manage the stocks and warehouse according to Tdh warehouse and stock management procedures. 
•Undertake monthly physical stock inventory and ensure adequate amount of equipment and supplies are available.
•Organize IT visits and computers maintenance.
Security    
•Ensure the security and safety of the staff in their work premises and ensures the provision and setting up of necessary equipment. 
•Ensure timely and effective communication among Tdh staff for safety and security awareness and emergency response.
•Support Tdh management of all safety and security related incidents following Tdh procedures. 
•Advise Tdh management regarding decisions and measures on travelling, urban and rural movement, adequate staff behavior and conduct and emergency response to safety and security incidents.
•Refer any event or incident to the Country Delegate/ Country Representative and all relevant Tdh staff for preventive measures and responses to be taken to protect Tdh mandate, staff and operations.
•Maintain and improve of Tdh’s passive security infrastructure (bunkers, fences, alarms, etc.).
Procurement    
•Make sure that the procurement process is respected by all Tdh staff according to the Tdh Procurement Procedures.
•Update and keep an up-to-date database on local suppliers to be familiar with the local market for supplies and for service requirements: transport, maintenance and storage. 
•Collect the purchase requests and check that the forms are correctly filled before validation. Inform the line manager in case of difficulties.
•Carry on quotation and offers needed to make purchase.
•Make bid analysis.
•Order purchases and ensure their proper delivery.
Capacity building    
•Ensure a good level of staff security and support the development of a capacity building plan.
•Supervise and participate in capacity building needs assessment.
•Prepare (training materials, tools, follow up, etc.) and conduct training/ coaching according to the training needs identified, upon need.
Assessment & Evaluation

Monitoring & Reporting

•Monitor the adherence of safety and security measures and emergency response.

•Commit to ensure the best implementation possible of the Safeguarding Policy in Jordan;
•Commit to inform Child Safeguarding Focal Point and to deal with any cases, allegations, or possibility of transgression, even potential, of the Safeguarding Policy.
Other    
•Undertake all other duties that may be determined by the Admin & Finance Advisor and/or Country Representative and that are compatible with the job.
Requirement 
Experience 
1.Mandatory  at least 6 years of experience in the field of Logistic, Procurement and fleet management 
2.Mandatory previous experience in INGO, NGO as Senior Officer or Coordinator level
3.Knowledge on Project Management principles and project cycle 
4.Experience in coordination and representation
5.Preferable experience in supervising a team 
Personal and technical skills:
1.Good report writing skills
2.Good communication and negotiation skills
3.Ability to work independently and as part of a team
4.Flexible, willing to travel 
5.Good computer skills
6.Good organization skills
7.Sense of humor , dynamic, pro-active
Education and knowledge:

2.Preferable university degree in Administration, Logistic or Economic , or other relevant area
3.Understanding and commitment to child’s rights and child protection issues
4.Preferable Experience working with Excel database

The Consultancy
 
Oxfam, on behalf of the LEADERS Consortium (ACTED, Danish Refugee Council, Care, Oxfam and Save the Children), seeks to engage a consultant/consultancy team to conduct research into the local level policy environment for micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in Jordan with a focus on Irbid, Mafraq and Zarqa over the next two months. The research should provide a comprehensive review of the challenges and obstacles facing MSMEs and provide recommendations to improve the enabling environment for MSME growth in target areas.
 
Background
Jordan’s private sector is dominated by micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs). According to the 2013 Poverty Reduction Strategy, 89% of businesses employ 1-5 people, and a further 9% employ 20 or less. Moreover, micro, small and medium businesses employ 70% of the Jordanian workforce. However, according to the World Bank’s 2015 Doing Business Report, Jordan ranked 185 out of 189 economies in terms of the ease of getting credit, significantly lower than the MENA or OECD average. Generally in Jordan it has been observed the lack of clarity around the registration process drives many micro and small enterprises (MSEs) and start-ups to avoid registering and licensing their businesses. Therefore they remain in the informal realm, and are prevented from growing. This inhibits broad-based economic growth for the country. These challenges are starker for Syrians seeking to form and register businesses in Jordan. Likewise, women face particular challenges in access credit and navigating the complex registration processes, which further inhibits their access to resources and ability to earn an income.
While at the national level, clarity around regulations and policies for MSMEs is slowly emerging, it is less clear how well these are being implemented at local level. Similarly, there is a lack of awareness of local initiatives which may be in place to support the development of MSMEs. This research will remedy this gap in knowledge by looking at the local level implementation of national policies on MSMEs, assessing local government perception of their role and performance in areas of programme implementation and comparing that with the perception of local business leaders. Particular attention will be paid to gather the views of women business owners and Syrian business owners in areas of operation.
The Leaders Consortium  supported by the MADAD Trust Fund aims to contribute to the economic self-reliance, resilience and social stability of displacement-affected populations in Jordan and Lebanon. The programme aims at working towards enhancing economic stability of displaced and displacement-affected populations. The intervention targets 250,000 individuals in Jordan and Lebanon.
 
Consultancy Selection Criteria
The ideal consultant/consultancy team will have a proven track record of research project management, including experience organising and conducting field research, knowledge of the policy environment in Jordan, including economic and labour policies and demonstrable knowledge of economic development, political economy, MSME development, labour markets. The ability to write clearly and concisely in English will be critical to this piece of research work.  In addition, established networks with policy makers is desirable.

The Middle East and Commonwealth of Independent States (MECIS) region implements and manages programmes in Yemen, Occupied Palestinian Territories, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, Jordan, Russia, Tajikistan, Armenia, and Georgia.
Programmes within the MECIS region reflect Oxfam’s approach to work across the globe. We support self-reliance, not dependency, and to complement our work on the ground we strive to secure lasting change through our campaigning.
We also put women at the heart of all we do. The majority of people living in poverty are women and girls, and so this focus helps us to achieve our mission to overcome poverty and suffering.

PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY: Mercy Corps has been working hand-in-hand in Jordan with local communities and partners since 2002 to implement US, UN, EU, UK, and private donor funded projects. In 2006 Mercy Corps began implementation of a highly successful $30M USD Community Based Initiative for Water Demand Management (CBIWDM) project, which worked with 175 community-based organizations across Jordan to promote water demand management and energy saving and generating technologies. In addition, Mercy Corps is helping meet the immediate needs of vulnerable Syrian refugees in Jordan, supporting them and their Jordanian host communities to meet urgent and basic needs by developing and supporting short and medium-term economic opportunities while also improving the capacity of shared infrastructure and services, such as water systems, in order to serve an increased population. The Water Innovations Technology (WIT) project is a 5-year $35 million USAID-funded program designed to catalyze water conservation in Jordan. Jordan is the fifth most water poor country on earth and urgent action is required to make better use of existing water resources due to economic, population, and climate pressures. Position Description: Health Workforce Competency Component Lead
Overview:
As a global cooperative agreement, HRH2030 supports USAID/Washington and field missions in strengthening human resources for health (HRH) across 42 priority countries to increase the accessibility, availability, acceptability, and quality of the health workforce needed to improve health outcomes and advance universal health coverage. HRH2030 is designed to 1) increase performance and productivity of the health workforce, 2) increase the number, skill mix, and competency of the health workforce, 3) strengthen HRH/HSS leadership and governance capacity and, 4) increase the sustainability of investment in the health workforce. With Chemonics International as the prime implementing partner, HRH2030 consortium partners include Palladium, URC, ThinkWell, AIHA, Amref Health Africa, Open Development, and the Royal Tropical Institute (KIT).
In support of Jordan’s Ministry of Health (MOH) Objective #5 to “Deploy and manage human resources efficiently and effectively,” and the Jordan Vision 2025 aim of achieving universal health coverage for all Jordanians, USAID/Jordan seeks to strengthen national public-sector HRH systems through a robust, targeted set of activities strategically linked to achieve the following goal: Strengthened health workforce for better health services. This goal will be realized through the attainment of three main objectives:
1)   Improved Human Resources Practices at the Ministry of Health by strengthening human resources systems and staff capacity in order to efficiently and effectively motivate, retain, and distribute the workforce.
2)    Improved Health Workforce Competency by training emerging health leaders and supervisors and supporting a national continuing professional development system for the health workforce.
3)    Strengthened National HRH Governance by improving national HRH policies and strategic plans and improving HRH data for decision-making.
Interventions to achieve these three objectives will be aimed at all levels of the health system: the central MOH level, the de-centralized MOH directorates at the governorate level, and the national HRH governance level.
Responsibilities:
The Health Workforce Competency Component Lead reports to the HRH2030 Project Director in Jordan and is directly responsible for providing a broad range of technical direction to accomplish Result 2: Improved Health Workforce Competency, and will contribute to Result 1: Improved HR Practices at the MOH. Specifically, the Health Workforce Competency Component Lead will lead HRH2030 project activities related to health facility management and leadership (HFML) training, supportive supervision systems, skill competencies, development of national continuing professional development (CPD) system, and workforce evaluation. The position will assist with capacity-building of HRD systems and staff at the MOH.
 
This position works with high-level officials, HRD staff, and emerging leaders to improve HRD functions and management at the MOH. The Health Workforce Competency Component Lead also coordinates with other national health sector stakeholders, including the High Health Council (HHC), Royal Medical Services, university hospitals, Jordanian Medical Council, Jordanian Nursing Council, and the private sector to support a national CPD system. The position oversees internal capacity building, reporting, and communications of HRD, HFML, and CPD activities.
 
Primary responsibilities will include but will not be limited to the following:

Develop, coordinate, and ensure delivery of trainings related to HFML for emerging leaders at the MOH aligned with succession planning.
Provide technical assistance, such as assessments, resource development, and oversight, to promote supportive supervision as an accepted and practiced management style at the health directorates and flowed down to MOH health facilities.
Establish and work through a committee of experts appointed by the Minister of Health to develop a national CPD system to be included in the five-year national HRH policy and strategy, including acting as the secretariat of the committee, assessing the current CPD environment, drafting CPD documents for stakeholder review, tracking progress, and advocating with stakeholders to obtain buy-in and endorsement.
Develop, coordinate, and ensure delivery of training and technical assistance activities to build the MOH capacity of HRD staff and systems.
Assist the MOH to develop its training plan and HRD policy and strategy.
Prepare annual work plans to meet HRH2030 goals and objectives related to HRD, HFML training, and CPD issues.
Proactively strategize to troubleshoot anticipated issues and challenges.
Provide targeted capacity building staff in subject matter expertise to HRD and other stakeholders as directed.
Track and report in writing progress against established work plans and milestones quarterly, annually, and upon request.
Provide regular updates to the HRH2030 leadership team.

 
Qualifications:

Masters degree in a relevant field required, medical, nursing, or doctorate degree preferred;
At least 10 years of experience working on human resources development, leadership and management training, and/or continuing professional development, preferably in the health sector;
High level of diplomacy and ability to successfully engage a broad range of stakeholder representatives;
Demonstrable leadership skills and experience in assessing, training, and building the capacity of CPD or HRD related staff, systems, and policies.
Experience working with USAID-funded projects highly preferred;
Excellent communication (oral and written) skills, with demonstrated ability to write technical reports required;
Experience in coordination of high-level stakeholder meetings;
Computer literacy in word processing, spreadsheets, and preparation of graphs, tables, charts with Microsoft Office (including Word, Excel, and PowerPoint);
Fluency in English and Arabic required.

GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY: 
The Operations Manager - WIT program is a senior member of the Water Innovations Technology (WIT) program and is responsible for enabling excellence in all operations functions including Procurement, Logistics, Assets, Fleet, Warehousing, and HR. S/he ensures effective systems that support strategy for healthy, robust and integrated functions of local team members.
S/he will collaborate closely with the Deputy Chief of Party (DCoP), Chief of Party (CoP) and other senior managers in the WIT program and Jordan country team. The Operations Manager - WIT program will oversee Operations; supervise all of these department heads; ensure that appropriate systems are in place for the effective and compliant support of the program. S/he will provide guidance in the proper administration of policies and procedures and liaise closely with Mercy Corps' Procurement, Administration and Logistics Management (PALM) team. The Operations Manager WIT program will also provide continuous support and input to the DCoP and CoP concerning operational and strategic direction setting.
PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY:
Mercy Corps has been working hand-in-hand in Jordan with local communities and partners since 2002 to implement US, UN, EU, UK, and private donor funded projects. In 2006 Mercy Corps began implementation of a highly successful $30M USD Community Based Initiative for Water Demand Management (CBIWDM) project, which worked with 175 community-based organizations across Jordan to promote water demand management and energy saving and generating technologies. In addition, Mercy Corps is helping meet the immediate needs of vulnerable Syrian refugees in Jordan, supporting them and their Jordanian host communities to meet urgent and basic needs by developing and supporting short and medium-term economic opportunities while also improving the capacity of shared infrastructure and services, such as water systems, in order to serve an increased population. Mercy Corps now looks to start a new, multi-year USAID grant to build on lessons learned from 9 years of strong community development work in water resource management.
The Water Innovations Technology (WIT) project is a 5-year $35M USD USAID-funded program designed to catalyze a movement for water conservation in Jordan. The WIT program will contribute to the overall objective of conserving water in Jordan, through the adoption and proven water-saving technologies and techniques, by achieving three integrated outcomes: 1) Water conserving technologies and behavior changes are adopted at the agricultural, community and household levels; 2) Access to fmancing for adoption of water conservation technology is improved; and 3) Institutions strengthened to support water saving technologies.
ESSENTIAL JOB FUNCTIONS:
Strategy and Vision

Provide program support, coordination, supervision and monitoring designed to meet program objectives of WIT program.
Contribute to the WIT program strategic planning process and provide regular updates.

Personal Leadership

Consistently demonstrate flexibility, resilience and ability to maintain positive relationships and composure, even under difficult circumstances.
Maintain high ethical standards and treat people with respect and dignity.
Demonstrate an awareness of his/her own strengths and development needs.

Representation

Interface with stakeholders responsible for coordinating all supply shipments via the appropriate approval processes in coordination with MC Country Logistics Team.
Communicate with local partners as well as sub-grantees, to verify their systems and that they understand and follow all appropriate procedures and archiving.

PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY:
The Mercy Corps Finance Department is responsible for all financial functions in Amman, including accounting, payments and banking, payroll, budgeting, financial reporting, and grant financial management and compliance.  The Mercy Corps Finance Department ensures compliance with donor regulations as well as Mercy Corps’ internal policies and procedures.  In its role as a support to the Program Department, the Finance Department provides timely reports and assistance to the Country Director and the Program team to ensure that financial resources are used efficiently and effectively.                                   
GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY:
Working in the Finance Department under the direction of the Finance Manager, the Subgrant Compliance & capacity Manager is responsible for all subgrant financial department and therefore all financial responsibilities related to sub granting. He will work closely with all sub-grantees and Program/Project Managers. His/her responsibilities include monitoring and building up financial capacities of the subgrantees.  S/he is responsible to ensure sub grants / sub grantees are in compliance with donor and Mercy Corps sub-awards policies and procedures from the pre-financial assessment to close out and provide sub grantees adequate and effective training, coaching and financial tools. The Subgrant Compliance & Capacity Building Manager is responsible for supervising training and mentoring subgrant compliance officers, assistants and coordinator.
ESSENTIAL JOB FUNCTIONS:
Sub-Grant Financial Management:  

Administer the partnership / subgranting processes in accordance with MC subgrant manual.
Review, analyze and ensure financial pre-award assessments/and other due diligence are performed, recommends special conditions, modifications to the subgrant agreement and/or monitoring plan to lessen financial and compliance risks.
Assist the program staff for the review of partners’ subgrants budgets to ensure alignment with activities, time effort, donor regulations.
Prepare and Review of subgrant agreements waivers, approvals, contract modifications, budget modifications and extensions” in conjunction with Mercy Corps headquarters, select subgrant agreement type, draft subgrant agreement (or provide relevant information to HQ to draft sub-grant) and negotiate agreements with selected partners.
Develop partner monitoring plans and ensure they are followed up with his staff, review financial monitoring of partners and the financial monitoring visit reports (“compliance reports”).
Review sub-grant financial reports prepared by his staff and supporting document and provide constructive feedback to beneficiaries and PM/ Finance Manager as necessary.
Train and Supervise sub grant finance staff in their functions (Maintain subgrant tracking as well as financial files in accordance with the Field Finance Manual, sub awards manual, ensure that financial reports are entered in navigator in a timely manner, the Navigator records meet MC standards, subgrantees payments are reconciled and posted).
Identify vulnerability and risk within current subgrants and proactively develop corrective actions
Follow up on all subgrant compliance issues and audits and document resolutions.
Prepare subgrant close-outs ensuring that all requirements of the subgrant agreement have been met and that subgrant funds have been properly settled.
Assist Finance Manager on preparing management response and plan of actions of Internal and/or External audits.
Work very closely within the Finance department to facilitate grant projections, disbursement and reporting.

Capacity Strengthening and Support to Local Partners/CBOs:

Work closely with partners to identify capacity development priorities in financial management, reporting, etc.
Responsible for drafting, developing and monitoring capacity development plans for MC partners.
Assist sub grantees in developing budgets as needed and makes sure that the subgrantees understand their budgets, agreements and donor regulations. 
Participate in the development of the overall the partnership / sub granting capacity building strategy.
Manage and monitor finance and compliance trainings for local partners, making visits to partners’ offices, providing necessary resources or materials, etc.
Responsible for financial management capacity support to partners through on-going support, coaching, and mentoring throughout sub-grant lifecycle and in line with agreed-upon capacity development plans.
Collaborate closely with program staff to ensure capacity development support to partners is tailored, targeted and responsive to their organizational needs and priorities.
Creatively problem solve with partners to develop protocols and procedures that are both compliant and contextually appropriate.
Work with partners to develop financial procedures and cash transfer/ movement mechanisms as needed and on developing cash handling protocols as required.
Follows up on financial capacity development plan effectiveness and participates in lessons learned sessions to create actionable items for future improvement for both Mercy Corps and its partners.

Operational Finance:-

Be familiar with the field finance manual, procurement manual and any additional MC Jordan policies;
Be knowledgeable and stay abreast of Mercy Corps financial sub awards policies and procedures and Donor regulations
Conduct himself/herself both professionally and personally in such a manner as to bring credit to Mercy Corps and to not jeopardize its humanitarian mission.
Other duties as assigned

Supervisory Responsiblity: Subgrant compliance and capacity building Assistants, Officers and Coordinators.
ACCOUNTABILITY
REPORTS DIRECTLY TO: Finance Manager
WORKS DIRECTLY WITH: Project Officers, Coordinators, Manager and Field Finance staff if any
KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE: 

Seven or more years of finance experience, including budgeting and grant management or auditing
A university degree in finance, accounting or a related business field is required. 
Three years of experience in the Finance Department of a non-governmental organization
Good understanding of major international donor rules and non-profit accounting
Prior experience with computerized general ledger software
Advanced computer skills in MS Office programs, particularly Excel. 
Strong analytical skills coupled with a solid understanding of financial and procurement systems; Prior auditing experience is considered a plus.
Excellent oral and written English skills

SUCCESS FACTORS:
The ability to interact effectively with international and national personnel is required.  A demonstrated ability to multi-task, meet deadlines.  A high professional standard of finance and procurement ethics as well as the willingness and ability to enforce compliance with Mercy Corps and donor policies and procedures is essential.  The ability to effectively monitor subgrantee compliance as well as to provide support and training for subgrantee personnel is critical.  The Subgrant Compliance & Capacity Building Manager must be willing to travel to Mercy Corps field offices, subgrantee offices and project sites.

Terre des hommes Lausanne  (Tdh-Lausanne) has been working in Jordan since 2007, starting its intervention with the Iraqi refugees, carrying out projects related to child protection (CP), psychosocial support (PSS), and then juvenile justice (JJ) in 2011. Since April 2012, Tdh has been intervening in the northern host communities, and since April 2013, in the Marjeeb al-Fahrood/Emirati Jordanian Camp (EJC). The aim is to support children and their families affected by the Syrian crisis and to strengthen the CP mechanisms in the camp and hosting communities.
Since the start of the crisis in Syria in March 2011 and following a continuous deterioration of the humanitarian situation, more than 640,000 people have sought refuge in Jordan. 
General Responsibilities and Principles
With the support and under the supervision of the Juvenile Justice Project Manager, The Senior Project Officer (SPO) is responsible to implement the daily activities contributing to improve the ability of juvenile justice stakeholders to protect children at risk or in contact with the law, through all the judicial proceedings.
The incumbent commits to observe discretion on any information related to the organization functioning.
The incumbent will conduct his or her duties in respect of the Charter of Terre des hommes (Tdh) and Tdh Safeguarding Policy. 
Tdh intervenes without any affiliation for politics, religion or financial profit. The incumbent will direct his or her activities and engagements without preoccupation of political, racial or religious affiliation.
Tdh expects that its staff and contractors’ professional conduct reflect proper behaviour in accordance with local culture and traditions. The incumbent assures the moral protection of the name of Tdh and defends in all circumstances the interests of the movement.

TSN seeks a Budget Officer to maintain the financial records of TSN JORDAN by accurately recording the day to day financial transactions into the regional finance database and accounting system as well as managing the budgets of assigned projects whilst ensuring accurate reporting at al times.

•1+ year of budget management experience.
•Knowledge of generally accepted accounting principles.

Background/IRC Summary: The International Rescue Committee responds to the world’s worst humanitarian crises and helps people to survive and rebuild their lives. Founded in 1933 at the request of Albert Einstein, IRC offers life-saving care and life-changing assistance to refugees forced to flee from war or disaster. At work today in more than 40 countries and in 22 U.S. cities, IRC restores safety, dignity and hope to millions who are uprooted by conflict or disaster. IRC leads the way from harm to home.
The Syria crisis is often described as the worst humanitarian catastrophe since the end of the Cold War. Inside Syria, 7.6 million people are internally displaced and 12.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance, with 4.8 million in hard-to-reach areas. There are over 4 million Syrian refugees in neighboring countries. This is no short-term humanitarian episode. The devastating human consequences to huge numbers of people will endure for decades. The destruction of relationships, communities, livelihoods, homes and infrastructure will take years to repair.
IRC is offering a robust humanitarian response to the Syria crisis with an annual budget in excess of $140 million and a rapidly expanding portfolio, supported by more than 1,250 staff in the region. IRC is undertaking programs in Syria and the neighboring countries of Turkey, Iraq, Lebanon and Jordan in the fields of health, child protection, education, women’s protection and empowerment, NFI and food distribution, cash assistance, water and sanitation, and livelihood programming. Our work in these challenging settings gives rise to some of the most pressing issues facing contemporary humanitarian action, including questions of access, security, funding and coordination.
The IRC Jordan program was established in 2007 and is operating programs in Jordan and southern Syria with an annual budget of $36 million. The IRC currently implements health, women’s protection and empowerment, child protection and economic recovery and development programming in northern Jordan; the IRC is also currently providing humanitarian assistance in southern Syria in the sectors of protection, health and economic recovery and development through partnerships with Syrian NGOs and provision of life-saving relief items.

All NRC employees are expected to work in accordance with the organization’s core values: dedication, innovation, inclusivity and accountability. These attitudes and believes shall guide our actions and relationships. 
 

Role and responsibilities

The overall objective of the NRC Jordan Youth Programme is to ensure that Youth become and remain active and engaged members of their communities, while employing a Do No Harm lens in terms of programme assessment and implementation.
 
NRC will provide access to structured learning and social engagement opportunities for Syrian and Jordanian youth. Opportunities will vary according to the diverse educational needs of the youth population in and out of camps, taking into consideration sensitivities of engaging youth and linking where possible and appropriate to opportunities to enter the informal workforce, return to education, pursue higher education and/or for personal, professional and social development.
 
The Technical Youth Officer is responsible for carrying out technical support activities and liaison with NRC staff and community staff in Youth Centres. The Technical Youth Officer is primarily responsible for developing curricula and learning material, as well as tools for learning assessment and evaluation. The additional focus of the position is to assess and respond to facilitators’ needs in the NRC youth centres.
 
Generic responsibilities 

Provides direction, coordinate tasks and gives instructions to staff.
Monitor the progress of the team activities and ensures they are implemented conform planning, quality standards, budget and (donor) guidelines.
Develop with the assigned team, Quarterly activity plans.
Ensure compliance with NRC policies CC tools, handbooks and guidelines.
Ensure that projects activities target the needs of beneficiaries, explores and asses new and better ways to meet their needs.
Represent NRC, liaison and collaborate with relevant local authorities and/or stakeholders.
Define the specific programs learning outcomes expected to work on by teachers and achieve by students.
Coordinate NRC staff to ensure that all activities are carried out with the active inclusion of all community members (especially girl children and adolescents, female and male parents, teachers and guardians and children with disabilities and special needs.)
Work with project officers and the monitoring and evaluation unit to ensure that data is collected and recorded appropriately.

Specific responsibilities 

Overall responsibility for all site level activities on training and curricula development
Advise in the current curricula and work towards improving centers educational resources
Act as focal point for all curricula development and mapping exercise to match the programme needs.
Implement policy and implementation synergies with other CCs and agencies at site level
Develop monthly activity and work plan.
Represent at camp level WGs as delegated by PM
Identify capacity building needs of staff/community .following NRC procedures.   
Advise PM/PCs on capacity building needs and opportunities. 
Inform programme development (focus on needs and opportunities) at site level, with strong basis in M&E
Prepare monthly reports on activities
Ensure M&E correctly conducted and reported

Ensure proper documentation and information security of all activities including teachers’ time sheets, and training records.

Mainstreaming Gender in the public sector
 
1. Background
USAID Takamol Gender Program focuses on mainstreaming gender at the policy, national, and community levels. The objectives of the Program are: to expand social dialogue on gender equality, strengthen enforcement and advocacy for female empowerment, and to improve women and girl-centered services. The Program is funded by the USAID and implemented by IREX.
USAID Takamol Gender Program delivers support mechanisms, in-kind assistance, training, and/or grants to build the capacity of national and grassroots organizations including civil society actors, media, government ministries, as well as supports USAID Implementing Partners to achieve gender equity and female empowerment. 
Upon completion of phase one gender audit, USAID-TAKAMOL continuous provision for technical assistance to mainstream gender in the GOJ responding to KAA proposals, in a phase two initiative. Two institutions, The Social Security Cooperation and the Ministry of Social Development have expressed willingness and officially request USAID- TAKAMOL to be considered for phase two gender audit. The outcome of the assignment is to conduct a gender audit. The latter is a tool that should enable gender mainstreaming at the respected ministries. After the endorsement of MOSD and SSC top management, both governmental institutions formulate gender audit teams at their respective institutions and received the following trainings, in preparation to the gender audit: Introduction to gender, Gender Based result strategic planning, Mainstreaming Gender Analysis, Human Development and gender sensitive indicators, qualitative and quantitative research, Gender Responsive Budgeting and organizational gender mainstreaming and development. This concept note defines clearly the nature of a further yet vital technical assistance needed for gender audit phase 2: Capacity building using SPSS and analyzing data quantitatively is identified as a specific skill and tool that remain needed after eight technical trainings delivered to Gender Audit Teams GATs.
 
 2. Objective
This Training aims at achieving the following objectives:
 Objective #1: To aid finalizing the gender audit process
Objective #2: Analyze the quantitative data of their institutions.  
 
 3. Scope of Work
The trainer is expected to perform the following tasks:
Task 1: Using the programming of SPSS via laptops (provided by USAID-Takamol) for the purpose of statistical analysis.
Task 2: Training participants on Comparison of more than 2 means: Analysis of variance.
Task 3: Training participants on data entry and data clustering per key categories provided.
Task 4: Training participants on   Description of Data and Multiple Linear Regression Using SPSS  Analysis
 Task 5: Training participants on Trend Analysis
Task 6: Training participants on Correlation Analysis
Task 7: Training on how to comment on data analysis findings
 Task 8: How to transfer data on Excel into SPSS
Task 9: Training on Working with the Data Editor/syntax
 
4. Consultant Expertise 

At least a BA Degree or equivalent in Information Technologies, Statistics, Demography, or any other related technical field with special expertise in data management;
At least 8 years’ experience in data processing and analysis;
At least 6 years’ experience in using SPSS;
At least 5 years’ experience in providing related training;
Proven ability of presentation of complex data answer specific questions

 
5. Technical Direction
The Consultant will report to the Senior Component Leader on Policy and Advocacy. Feedback and consultation are ongoing with the Chief of Party
 
6. Application Process
To be considered, consultants must provide the following information:

CV highlighting the expertise in providing the services required
Cover letter to include a statement describing the consultant’s capability for completing the assignment and proposed daily rate
Signed Biodata containing justification for consultant’s proposed daily rate

Background: The International Rescue Committee responds to the world’s worst humanitarian crises and helps people to survive and rebuild their lives. Founded in 1933 at the request of Albert Einstein, IRC offers life-saving care and life-changing assistance to refugees forced to flee from war or disaster. At work today in more than 40 countries and in 22 U.S. cities, IRC restores safety, dignity and hope to millions who are uprooted by conflict or disaster. IRC leads the way from harm to home.
CONTEXTUAL BACKGROUND:
The Syria crisis is often described as the worst humanitarian catastrophe since the end of the Cold War. Inside Syria, 7.6 million people are internally displaced and 12.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance, with 4.8 million in hard-to-reach areas. There are 4 million Syrian refugees in neighboring countries. This is no short-term humanitarian episode. The devastating human consequences to huge numbers of people will endure for decades. The destruction of relationships, communities, livelihoods, homes and infrastructure will take years to repair.
IRC is offering a robust humanitarian response to the Syria crisis. With an annual budget in excess of $140 million and a rapidly expanding portfolio, supported by more than 1,250 staff in the region, IRC is undertaking programs in Syria and the neighboring countries of Turkey, Iraq, Lebanon and Jordan in the fields of health, child protection, education, women’s protection and empowerment, NFI and food distribution, cash assistance, water and sanitation, and livelihood programming. Working in coordination with the humanitarian community and the Government of Jordan, the IRC's assistance programs for Syrian refugees in Jordan include both camp-based and urban-based refugee assistance. Our work in these challenging settings gives rise to some of the most pressing issues facing contemporary humanitarian action, including questions of access, security, funding and coordination.

BACKGROUND: 
Founded in 1933, the International Rescue Committee is one of the most prominent international organizations working in relief, rehabilitation, protection, post-conflict development, resettlement services and advocacy for those uprooted or affected by violent conflict and oppression. 
Working in coordination with the humanitarian community and the Government of Jordan, the IRC's assistance programs for vulnerable persons in Southern Syria includes assistance in the following sectors: women’s protection & empowerment, child protection, protection rule of law, cash assistance, primary health care service provision and community-based health.
SCOPE OF WORK:
With direct management support from the Senior Protection Manager, the Child Protection Manager plays a key role in leading project development and implementation, providing technical support and guidance to the IRC’s protection services, remote management of staff and/or partners inside southern Syria, and ensuring the delivery of quality child protection programming in Dohuk.
Key Working Relationships:
Position Reports to:  Senior Protection Manager
Position directly supervises:  Protection Officer
Indirect Reporting: Will work within IRC’s cross-border team, led by the Deputy Director (Programs)
Other Internal and/or external contacts: Regular coordination with other humanitarian actors and partners in Jordan and Syria.
Responsibilities:
Program Design, Support and Planning
• Project, technical and grant management of IRC cross border Child Protection services, including partner and staff management.
• Oversight of current IRC youth centers in southern Syria, ensuring high quality programming and implementation.
• Work closely with operations and grants to coordinate to ensure quality, timely, implementation and development of programs, including providing oversight over the budget versus actual, indicator tracking tools, and other grant management tools used by the IRC; participation in monthly grant review meetings; and regular monitoring of internal program purchase request tools.
• Development and implementation of training and technical support to mainstream child protection standards across all IRC cross border programs.
• Ensure donor compliance in program implementation and procurement.
• Take a lead role in design of new Child Protection projects, and proposal development.
• Ensure timely and correct narrative and quantitative reporting from inside Syria.
• Monitor program developments and play key role in the identification and development strategic opportunities and other business opportunities.
• Play a key role with the Senior Protection Manager in the development of proposals to ensure continued programming.
Capacity Building and Staff Development
• Provide ongoing mentoring and technical support to staff and partners on their case management services, ensuring case management forms/tools/processes, supervision systems for case workers and procedures for handling case information follow best practices and standards.
• Provide ongoing mentoring and technical support to staff on all areas of programming.
Project Monitoring and Evaluation
• Work with IRC Monitoring team and partner organisations to ensure a safe and confidential mechanism for collecting information on project activities is implemented.
• Support the design of monitoring and evaluation tools that are contextually appropriate and will allow the IRC to measure the impact of programming.
• Ensure that all internal and external reporting requirements are met and that reports are of a high quality and submitted on time.
Required Qualifications
• Minimum 4 years of experience from  which minimum 2 years are in a managerial level   of child protection program management experience,
• Relevant qualification in social work, social sciences, public health, community health, or related field,
• Demonstrated experience with capacity building and training,
• Solid expertise in designing and implementing monitoring and evaluation tools and processes,
• Proposal writing and development skills,
• Excellent relationship-building, interpersonal skills and the ability to liaise diplomatically,
• Solid ability to provide leadership, management, team-building, coaching, and development for staff,
• Strong negotiation skills essential with experience in conflict resolution desirable,
• Experience of working with local stakeholders and partners,

Background/IRC Summary: Founded in 1933, the International Rescue Committee (IRC) is a leading international organization working in relief, rehabilitation, protection, post-conflict development, resettlement services and advocacy for those affected by the world’s worst humanitarian crises.  At work today in over 40 countries and 22 U.S. cities, the IRC restores safety, dignity and hope to millions who are uprooted and struggling to endure.
IRC is currently addressing the needs of war-affected Syrians from several operational bases in the region. The IRC’ activities in the region form part of an over-arching humanitarian response in Jordan, Lebanon, Turkey and Iraq to assist refugees, IDPs and conflict-affected Syrians survive conflict and displacement.
Working in coordination with the humanitarian community and the Government of Jordan, the IRC's assistance programs for vulnerable persons in Southern Syria includes assistance in the following sectors: women’s protection & empowerment, child protection, protection rule of law, cash assistance, primary health care service provision and community-based health.
Job Overview/Summary:
The Senior Reporting and Monitoring Officer (SRMO) will act as the lead focal point for data collection, service monitoring (qualitative and quantitative) and report preparation for the IRC Jordan Cross Border Protection team. He/She will support technical managers to improve beneficiary data collection activities, take the lead in consolidating quantitative and narrative donor reports, and act as key focal point to the Monitoring and Evaluation Unit. The SRMO will play a key role in ensuring IRC protection services are feeding into global IRC reporting mechanisms.
Major Responsibilities:
Strengthening data collection and ensuring the quality of protection programs’ implementation
• Review, upgrade and monitor beneficiary and activity data collection and management systems, for both IRC partners and direct implementation.
• Act as focal point to technical protection managers for the accumulation and reporting of beneficiary and program data.
• Support the consolidation of both narrative and quantitative reports to donors (in collaboration with Monitoring and Grants teams).
• Act as focal point between IRC Monitoring team and Protection technical units for monitoring and reporting activities.
• Ensure timely and accurate routine data collection according to the monitoring plan.
• Developing an effective documentation system to keep track of data source documents.
• Support the development of monitoring methods and questions for protection activities, while ensuring a do-no-harm approach.
• Support the development of a stronger evidence base for IRC protection services.
• Develop and guide the implementation of appropriate monitoring and data collection tools for services.
• Maintain a monthly indicator and achievement tracker across all protection grants and teams.
• Become knowledgeable of, and act as protection focal point for IRC global M&E initiatives.
• Build the capacity of protection technical teams and implementing partners in data collection, monitoring and reporting.
•  Ensure timely and accurate routine data collection.
• Support the programs in developing an effective documentation system to keep track of data source documents.
• Work with the programs’ ICT4P/data staff to analyze the data to monitor the indicators’ progress and highlight the main trends and changes.
Staff management
The SRMO will not be line managing any internal staff. S/he might supervise and train volunteers / assessors to execute data collection and data entry assignments, if needed.
 
Professional Standards
The IRC and IRC workers must adhere to the values and principles outlined in the IRC Way - Standards for Professional Conduct.  These are Integrity, Service, and Accountability.  In accordance with these values, the IRC operates and enforces policies on Beneficiary Protection from Exploitation and Abuse, Child Safeguarding, Anti Workplace Harassment, Fiscal Integrity, and Anti-Retaliation.

The USAID Community Engagement Program (CEP) builds on the work of previous development programs to increase the efforts of civil society and government to work together to meet the needs of citizens. The program is comprised of three primary components: 1) Expand NGO, community organization, professional association and government efforts to build resilience and address cohesion-related challenges; 2) Increase civil society government-private sector cooperation in building resilience and addressing cohesion-related challenges; and 3) Strengthen skills and build other capacity relevant to community and national cohesion.

PROGRAM/DEPARTMENT SUMMARY:
Mercy Corps exists to alleviate suffering, poverty, and oppression by helping people build secure, productive, and just communities. Since the beginning of the Syrian civil war over five years ago, Mercy Corps has worked to address the urgent needs of over 4 million people both inside Syria and in neighboring countries.  The program will be implemented through a local team and/or local and regional partners and will be managed remotely from the Amman office, Jordan.
 
This position is dependent on funding.
 
GENERAL POSITION SUMMARY:
The Finance Officer will be embedded in the programs team and supported by the Regional Finance teams and will work closely with the programs teams and partners to ensure implementation and financial reporting is in accordance with donor rules and requirements and Mercy Corps policies and procedures. The Finance Officer will actively support the implementation of cash transfer programming, including managing the funds and financial reconciliation and facilitating payments. The other significant part of this role is to work together with partners (sub-grant recipients) implementing humanitarian projects to review and verify their financial reporting, carry out due diligence and provide capacity development support regarding financial related matters. 
 
ESSENTIAL JOB FUNCTIONS: 
 
Operational Finance

Design and manage the financial system to implement and manage a cash transfer program, including tracking of funds disbursed and reconciliation (in conjunction with programs team) and payments made, in accordance with Mercy Corps policies and procedures and to ensure compliance with donor rules and requirements. 
Develop and maintain Standard Operating Procedures (for financial matters) as may be necessary.  
Ensure payments are made on a timely basis and supported with all relevant and accurate supporting documentation. 
Record cash payments daily on Navigator and ensure all supporting documents are attached to the payment vouchers.
Prepare and/or review all documentation for monthly consultants’ and monitors’ payments (including wire transfer request, timesheets etc. and file) and other payments as needed. 
In conjunction with the finance team, understand, track and review possible cash transfer mechanisms in the region and consider the financial and other implications for these.
Uphold and promote a high standard of financial controls among the team.
Support the team and partners to understand which financial forms, templates and documents need completed and when.

1. USAID Community Engagement Project Background
The USAID Community Engagement Project is a five-year project funded by the United States
Agency for International Development (USAID), and implemented by Global Communities
(formerly CHF International), in collaboration with Jordanian partners; The program works with
local partners to strengthen community engagement in the context of regional volatility and
transitions associated with domestic policy reform, economic conditions and demographics.
The goal of USAID CEP is to leave behind stronger, more cohesive and resilient partner
communities. This goal will be achieved by working through, and building the capacity of,
Community Enhancement Teams (CETs), municipalities/local governments, and Community
Based Organizations (CBOs) as key stakeholders to:

 Engage in a continuous, conflict-sensitive participatory process of identification and prioritization of stressors;
Develop immediate and long-term solutions by accessing available resources through collaboration and partnerships with relevant stakeholders (including, when appropriate, informal leaders); and
Utilize effective and transparent communication mechanisms in support of increased community cohesion.

Throughout implementation, USAID CEP applies transparency, Do No Harm, and project-focused
implementation principles. Implemented through 3 field offices in Irbid, Mafraq, and Tafileh,
USAID CEP operates in the following 20 communities:

 Irbid: Hay Jalama, Dabbet Nimer, Yarmouk Al-Jedida, Mo’ath Bin Jabal, Khalid Bin Al Waleed, Al Wastiyah, No’aimeh, Al Taybeh.
 Mafraq: Hay Al-Hussein/Fdain, Hay Al-Janoubi, Al-Sarhan, Salheyeh w Nayfeh, SabhaDafyaneh, Um Aljmal, Hosha.

Tafileh: Beseira, Ein Al Beyda, Al-Hassa; Al Mansoura, Tein and Hid.

Ma’an: Ma’an City.


Project Activities:
USAID CEP uses a transparent mobilization process as the entry point into partner communities,
conducting household perception surveys and facilitating community-wide meetings to identify
key stressors facing communities. We then work with communities to assist in the formation of
the CET, a group of 12-20 volunteers comprised of 50% women, 30% youth, two municipal
representatives and governor/district governor office representatives.
Throughout the life of the program, the CET serves not only as a key stakeholder, but also as
USAID CEP’s primary counterpart. In partnership with municipalities, local government entities,
CBOs, and others, CETs work on designing interventions that directly address communityidentified
stressors; facilitate implementation; mobilize the broader community for greater impact;
disseminate and collect information; and ensure that community voices are heard and represented.
Relying on a phased facilitative approach embedded in the USAID CEP Community Engagement
Methodology, the Project aims to transfer progressively increased levels of responsibility to the
CETs in support of sustainability. To affect the necessary behavior change to achieve the intended
goal of leaving behind stronger, more resilient communities, USAID CEP implements three sets
of integrated activities:

Community Engagement: Working closely with the CETs, USAID CEP facilitates the design and implementation of solutions for prioritized community-identified stressors. Over the life of the project, CETs are guided through four phases, each marked by increasing levels of responsibility and required contribution. Utilizing a flexible Program Fund mechanism, each CET works with stakeholders on implementing one municipal/government service support, community enhancement, youth, and gender project per each phase of implementation.
Networking: Networking activities are designed to strengthen the key stakeholders’ ability to form partnerships, mobilize additional resources, share experiences, and strengthen intra-community cohesion. Our networking activities include partnership initiatives supported by non-US government funding, peer exchanges, and networking events. In addition, USAID CEP has a pool of Cohesion Grants which are used to address stressors common to multiple communities.
Conflict Management and Mitigation (CMM): To ensure that key stakeholders are equipped to operate in a fluid, complex environment and can effectively respond to emerging challenges, USAID CEP incorporates basic CMM training and offers a response mechanism to shocks and emerging stressors through a Special Activities Fund.
Municipal Pilot Project: In Year four USAID CEP decided to design a pilot project targeted some partners municipalities “Greater Ma’an Municipality, Greater Mafraq  Municipality and New Ramtha Municipality” ) to find ways in which community engagement can be appropriately strengthened and institutionalized within regular municipal functions. These efforts are designed in support of the newly passed municipal and decentralization laws and in preparation for their implementation. For this purposes, the aim of the project assisting the targeted municipalities in strengthening – as necessary– the municipality’s ability to effectively engage citizens in municipal strategic planning and receive and respond to citizen feedback on service provision. These projects, with limited funding, will not focus on procurement of equipment and service strengthening. Rather, we envision supporting system and process strengthening related to citizen engagement.

CARE International began work in Jordan in 1948 to meet the needs of Palestinian refugees displaced with the creation of Israel. CARE’s vision is of a world in which poverty has been overcome and all people live in dignity and security. We hold gender equality to be a fundamental requirement for poverty reduction and social justice, and the area in which we see the most pressing need for global change in order to reach our vision. Together with gender inequality, we recognize humanitarian crises – including conflict, disasters and situations of chronic insecurity – as among the most important threats to realizing our vision for a just world. In partnership with others, we deliver impactful, sustainable and evidence-driven results because of our long-term commitment to communities and our focus on addressing the underlying causes of poverty and social injustice.
Within its 67 years of operation, CARE Jordan’s programs address the needs of both the Jordanian and refugee populations. Recognizing that women and children suffer disproportionally from poverty, CARE Jordan places special emphasis on working with women to create permanent social change.
Currently, our work in Jordan prioritizes the following program areas:
Humanitarian Response: People affected by humanitarian crises are better able to protect themselves and their families, and receive quality humanitarian assistance.
Women’s Empowerment: Women and girls are better able to promote their social, economic, political, civil and cultural rights and well-being.
Youth engagement and empowerment: Linking youth engagement with youth empowerment initiatives.
CARE Jordan’s humanitarian response strategy includes managing a protection program in the urban settings in Amman, Irbid, Zarka, Mafraq and Azrak town; comprising of information provision, case management, emergency cash assistance, non-food items, conditional cash for education, psychosocial support, and contributing to enhancing livelihood opportunities. In addition, CARE is providing community services in Azraq Camp, with the aim to improve access to vital services, improve participation, accountability and contribute to a dignified life of the Syrian refugees currently living in Azraq camp.
CARE Jordan’s Women Empowerment Program, focuses on (1) Women’s Economic Empowerment where women are able to earn a living in a dignified and sustainable manner. (2) Gender-based Violence; the prevalence and social acceptance of gender-based violence has significantly decreased, and (3) Women’s Voice where women and girls increasingly exercise their rights to participate in decision-making in public and private spaces, at all levels.
Youth engagement and empowerment: Linking youth engagement with youth empowerment initiatives, and resulting in the development of a CARE model embracing both concepts and with a distinct focus on female as well as male youth.

The purpose of the Monitoring and Evaluation Officer – Reporting (ME Officer, Reporting) position is to assist the Program quality manager in improving the overall quality of services provided to beneficiaries S/he is responsible for the supervision and delivery of reporting on project activities and deliverables. S/he provides information to the M&E Manager to facilitate linkage with all M&E functions to ensure a coordinated and coherent departmental deliverable.
 
This post will provide oversight and coordination of all the activities of all Urban program activities in accordance with agreed standards (eg. IASC and SEA) and programme principles. It collects and reviews feedback on the quality of work from all stakeholders: refugees, UNHCR, donors, collegiate NGOs, Government and non-Governmental agencies, CBOs and the public to develop the required reporting.
The unit supports the regular monitoring and evaluation of work and collates documentation required to generate information for all who may need it.  It has the following objectives:
